loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora A. is starting a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. Her main source of income comes from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. She is a 38-year-old woman living in the town of Faleasiu 3. She is married and has four school-age children.

Nora joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Nora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to rent land to raise crops.

Nora is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to rent land to raise additional crops. This will be her second loan from SPBD. Nora plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. (0)

About SPBD: SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

Mariarosa is now requesting a new loan of 1600 WST, which will be used to rent land to raise additional crops.  The loan will be the third loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. loans.name: Faapopo

texts.en:
Faapopo S., age 49, lives in the town of Matautu Lefaga Tai. She is married and has two grown children. To make a living, Faapopo raises cattle for sale. Faapopo has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 650 WST per month.

In 2008, Faapopo joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities. Faapopo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional animals.

Faapopo is now requesting a new loan in the amount of 1,500 WST, which will be used to build shelter for her livestock. The loan will be the second loan she has taken out from SPBD. Faapopo plans to use the additional revenue she expects the loan to generate to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is 57 years old and is married with seven children, only one of whom still lives at home. Nora dedicates herself to the sale of pork and regional foods such as “juanes” (a local rice dish), tamales (steam-cooked corn dough wrapped in banana leaves), and other local dishes. Nora’s husband is retired from working in a sawmill and receives a pension.

Nora has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for four years and is a member of the communal bank “Las Almendras” (“The Almonds”). Nora invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in purchasing pork for her food business. She plans to invest this loan of 1,200 soles in staple items to prepare her regional dishes, including rice, cornmeal (for making tamales), pork, condiments and firewood for grilling.

Nora is pleased to be working with Manuela Ramos as the organization lends her money to invest in her business while requiring very little paperwork. Nora’s goal is to eventually purchase two motorcycle taxis in order to have regular income with which to cover her expenses. She will generate this income by renting out these taxis daily to drivers.

loans.use: To buy rice, cornmeal, pork, condiments and firewood for preparing her local dishes

loans.name: Norma Isabel

texts.en:
Norma is 63 years old and is married with four adult children. Norma and her family live in the city of Pucallpa. Norma sells fish and "mazamorra D. maiz" (a local pudding-style dessert maD. from corn). Her husband is a fisherman. 

Norma has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for seven years and belongs to the communal bank "Las Almendras" (The Almonds). She invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in purchasing fish for sale. Norma plans to invest this loan of 1200 soles in fish traps as well as in peanuts and corn for the dessert that she makes.

Thanks to her loans from Manuela Ramos, Norma has been able to fix up her house and also invest in business ventures. In this way she is able to support both her husband and their small grandson who lives with them. Norma's goal is to eventually have her own clothing shop.

loans.use: To buy fish traps for husband's fishing business and peanuts and corn for making a dessert to sell.

texts.en:
Marya is the group leader of the Marya Group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses. Their requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani. 

Marya and Habiba want a loan for their tailoring business. They want to two new machines for their business. Bibi Howa wants a loan for her carpet-weaving business. Qadseya wants a loan for her husband’s fruit cart. With this loan, he will make a small shop to house his business. 

They want to explain that this loan is very useful to each one of them, because it can provide a good chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses, and become stronger in their business and in life. This group wants to thank everyone who participates in this loan to Afghanistan.

texts.en:
Saumu is a member of the Mungu Muweza borrower group.She is a 40-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of six children aged 23, 22, 26, 12, 7, 3 years. She also cares for one other dependent.

Ten years ago, Saumu started her own clothing business selling kanga (printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides) and vitenge (a traditional Tanzanian cloth with wax print). She works ten hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 50,000 Tsh.

This is Saumu’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more fabric. With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Saumu hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fabric to sell

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is a member of the Tujikomboe borrower group. She is a 30-year-old woman, is married and is the mother of four children aged 11, 10, 7, and 1 years.

Four years ago, Khadija started her own shop selling cooking oil, rice, etc. She works eight hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 TZS.

This is Khadija’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 450,000 in order to buy more commodities for her business.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Khadija hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities like cooking oil and rice for her business

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka started her own business selling fish two years ago. She is a 30-year-old woman, married and the mother of four children. Her children are ages 12, 10, 9 and 3 years old. Mwaka works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tsh.

Mwaka is a member of the Bega kwa Bega borrower group. This is Mwaka's second loan from BRAC. She requested 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more fish to sell. With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Mwaka hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing of new clothing and shoes for sale

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is a member of Tuwe macho borrower group. She is a 40-year-old woman, married and the mother of two children. Her children are aged 15 and 7.

Khadija started her own clothing business selling clothes two years ago. She works eight hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tsh.

This is Khadija's first loan from BRAC. She requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to use that loan to buy more clothes for sale.

With the profit she will receive from the use of this loan, Khadija hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Shahodat

texts.en:
A. Shahodat is a hard working woman and since 2001 has dedicated herself to selling a variety of fruits and vegetables in the central market of Shahrituz, Tajikistan. Shahodat characterized herself as happy and humble. She started her business with her savings which she had accumulated over a long period of time. She is the mother of 5 children that she would like to offer an education. Her biggest dream is to arrange the wedding of her son for which she works hard every day. To realize this dream, Shahodat now requests 2500 Somoni. With this loan she wants to buy more goods to increase her earnings. With your collaboration she’ll be able to realize her dream in a short time.     


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase the variety of fruits and vegetables she sells

loans.name: Leluu

texts.en:
Leluu is a member of the Tuaminiane borrower group. She is a 30-year-old woman, married and the mother of three children. Her children are aged 9, 6 and 2.

Leluu stated her own food business two years ago. She works eight hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tsh.

This is Leluu's first loan from BRAC. She requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more sugar, wheat and cooking oil.

With the profit she will from the use of this loan, Leluu hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy commodities like cooking oil, wheat and sugar

loans.name: Ruzigul

texts.en:
Since she was young, Ruzigul N.  has enjoyed the countryside. Her family dedicated themselves to cultivating fruits and vegetables and Ruzigul always imagined she’d be in the business of selling produce.  Fortunately she has realized this dream. She began to sell vegetables in small markets.  Little by little, she saved money so she could set up her own shop. Thanks to her efforts and the love she has for this business, Ruzigul’s business has been growing. Now Ruzigul believes it is the time to inject more capital into the business so that she can buy at wholesale and obtain better prices.  She is soliciting a loan of 1500 Somoni. With your help, Ruzigul will be able to move her business forward and offer her family a better future.    
        

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase capital to be able to buy wholesale

loans.name: Tujikomboe Group

texts.en:
Teresia is a member of the Tujikomboe borrower group. She is a 40-year-old woman, married and a mother of three children. Her children are aged 28, 25 and 20.

Teresia started her own tailoring business three years ago. She works eight hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tsh.

This is Teresia's first loan from BRAC. She requested 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more material for her business.

With the profit she will gain from the use of this loan, Teresia hopes to save money, to pay school fees, get more food for her family and expand her business.

Fatma, another member of the same borrower group, also requested a loan of 350,000 Tsh in order to expand her own business.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Miteda Group

texts.en:
Esther O., age 44, is a divorcee with two children ages 22 and 19 years.  She has had a table top business, where she sells fruits and vegetables for 11years.  She works daily from 9am until 6pm.     She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $122.

This will be Esther’s 1st  loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She hopes to use this loan to increase her stock.
	
Esther will share this loan with her loan group, Miteda,   which totals 21 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Esther is  3rd from right, front row.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn L. is from the village of Upper Puntod. She is 25 years old. Evelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Evelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Evelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Marijana

texts.en:
Marijana Antunović comes from Brgule, a village in Tuzla’s suburbs. She is 22 and unmarried. Marijana lives with her parents who work at a local company.

Marijana, however, is unemployed. She is requesting a loan of 1000 BAM from WWI (Žene za Žene International) to buy chickens and poultry food. She would like to earn money for herself and become more independent. Her parents are now supporting her and will give her a place to keep the chickens.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and poultry food

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en: Sarah N. is 40 years old and the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is married with four children, ages 23 to 7 years old, all of whom are still in school as she cares for one dependent. Sarah has had a retail shop and a hotel in Burunga T/C for over ten years, and it’s because of her customers’ loyalty that she has managed her businesses. She has a dream of transforming her hotel into a modern one and to have all her children educated. Sarah is a determined and hardworking lady and she needs a loan to help buy more food items and accessories like plates, spoons and folks for her hotel and for restocking her retail shop.

loans.use: Purchasing food items and dishware for her hotel, plus restocking the retail shop

loans.name: Ivy

texts.en:
Ivy M. is from the village of Upper Puntod. She is 27 years old. Ivy is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Ivy owns and operates a business selling pork products in the local community. Ivy has been in business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Ivy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ivy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Ivy is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ivy from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Slavica

texts.en:
Slavica Vareškić was born in 1962. She is a widow who comes from Brgule, a village near the town of Tuzla. Slavica lives with her son and daughter-in-law. Slavica is employed in the local press room and can earn enough to meet her basic needs. In addition, Slavica works in agriculture, raising pigs and chickens and growing vegetables. 

Slavica has been our client for four years and has already repaid four loans. She invested the funds from all of her previous loans in her agricultural work. Now she has requested a fifth loan of 3000 KM from WWI ( Žene za Žene International)  to invest in her poultry business. Slavica has developed a network for the sale of chicken meat and hopes to do well before the winter.

loans.use: To purchase poultry

loans.name: Vin

texts.en: C. is 50-year-old married woman and mother who is devoted to her five children, three of whom are students while the other two are married and have already started new homes. Today, C. owns a bicycle which she uses to sell a few products directly at her customers' houses. She sells items like vegetables, pork, and other meats, and is typically earning around of $2.50 a day in order to meet her family’s living needs. A portion of her family’s daily expense is contributed by her husband who makes fishing equipment for sale. C. is hardly transporting her wares to sell because her bicycle is slow. Therefore, she would like a loan of $300 to buy an old motor, which she will use to pick up her items to sell more quickly. Note: C.'s husband appears in the picture.

loans.use: To buy an old motor to use to pick up her items to sell more quickly

loans.name: Edirisa's Group

texts.en: Edirisa W. is the leader of his lending group in Ibanda. He is 68 years old and married with ten children, ages 33 to 9 years old, five of whom are in school. Edirisa owns and manages two businesses; he has a butcher shop and he is a farmer in Kyabahuura. From his businesses, he is able to make monthly profits of 230,000/= due to his loyal customers. Edirisa is striving to expand his business and to have a happy family. He is requesting a loan to be able to buy a cow for his butcher shop as well as to buy some produce for resale since this was not a favorable season for his farm due to the too much sunshine.

loans.use: To buy cow and produce for his business

loans.name: Marom

texts.en:
Mrs. Marom Y., 52, and her husband, Mr. Chantha Em, 54, have been married since 1983 and have four children: one son and three daughters. One of them iss married and lives in separate house, one is a garment factory worker and other two attend school. The family lives along National Road Number One, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Marom has been selling pickled papaya for two months. In addition, she also sells fruit. Her husband has been driving a motor taxi for two years. He wants to drive Tuk Tuk taxi because it would be better for him to earn income to support his family. Tuk Tuk is a motorbike with a passenger trailer in the back. 

Marom is asking for her first loan of $800 to purchase a passenger trailer to help fund her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase a passenger trailer

loans.name: Lay

texts.en: Lay S. is 26 years old and a resident of Pursat Province. She lives with her husband and their one lovely young child, in their small family home. Lay S. is currently a local farmer, growing rice and some vegetables. Her husband, Doeun Choeun, age 27, is a marble seller. Lay S. is looking for a loan to purchase a pair of water buffalo which she will use to supply her farming operations and to transport marble to sell. Note: Lay S. was not available for a photograph so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase a pair of water buffalo

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophea M., 36 (pictured with her husband), and her husband, Mr. Sina Noun, 39, live along National Road Number One about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2004 and have a young son.

Sophea has been a tailor for 8 years. In addition to her tailoring business, she sells second-hand clothes. Her husband has been a security guard for many years. She is applying for her first loan of $ 1,200 to purchase silk fabrics for her tailoring business and second-hand clothes to resell.

loans.use: To purchase silk fabrics for her tailoring business and second-hand clothes for resale.

loans.name: Sokden

texts.en:
Mr. Davit Pun, age 32, and his wife, Mrs. Sokden Y., age 28, live along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2001 and have two sons who attend school.

In the past, Davit and his wife sold soup and grilled meat in a small shelter in front of their house. Because there are lots of competitors in the same business, he decided to quit that business and now runs a new business. He buys batteries from a nearby village and sells them in the Phnom Penh market.

Davit is requesting his second loan of US $500 to purchase more batteries to resell.

(Davit's wife appears in the photograph.)

loans.use: To purchase batteries to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a buffalo

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 56 years old. She is married to Roland who is 65 years old. After many years of being together, they have not yet been blessed with a child. The couple lives peacefully in the village of Benito Soliven, Isabela. Since they do not have a child, the couple make themselves busy in their business to avoid sadness. 

To make a living and to continue life, Lydia and her husband joined hands in operating their simple eatery business located in their village. They sell the delicious “pancit batil patong” (the famous noodles in Isabela). Lydia is hoping to borrow PHP10, 000 to further expand their eatery. 

According to Lydia, their business is the only thing that gives them  hope and happiness and that’s why she wants the best for it. She wanted to expand their business to somehow elevate their simple ways of living. They wanted to have a stable business to help others, like their nieces and other relatives, whenever they have something to give, since the couple is known to be generous, especially because they have had no children all throughout their married life.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Fazil

texts.en:
Fazil was born in 1956. He is married and has two children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan, Fuzuli region, now settled in Fuzuli region, in Bala Bahmanli village.

Fazil has been in the cattle breeding business for seven years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy four calves to improve his cattle-breeding business.

loans.use: To buy four calves to improve his cattle-breeding business

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina B. is 55 years old and works as an eye specialist. As a doctor, she is also practicing her knowledge in operating a business in her optical clinic located at Tagaran, Cauayan City. She and her husband are already separated and she is left with their two children who are both college graduates. Her eldest, Eloisa, is 29 years old and currently working as an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker) in Dubai. Josefino, 25 years old, manages a store in their village.

Edwina is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to be used as additional capital in purchasing lenses and prints or optical stock for her business. In addition, she is also planning to put up another clinic at another location to reach out to those who are in need. According to her, she is charging lower prices for her lenses and sunglasses.

Edwina is hoping to obtain her loan because it will be of great help to her business. She has been working hard for a very long time for her children and for future needs. Being separated from her husband is quite difficult because she is the only one supporting her children. She tries to work hard to prove that she can also be a good parent to her children without their father. Providing them with a complete education is already a great achievement for her.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Aisha's Group

texts.en:
M. Aisha is a 52-year-old woman who is single with seven children of whom three are still in school. She also helps to take care of orphans and her other siblings.

Aisha has run a restaurant business in Lugazi central street market for sixteen years. She started with a very small restaurant preparing very little local foods but, with the coming of loans, she has been able to expand, hence making more profit. Her business area is very competitive with very big hotels and restaurants but, because of her cooking skills and good customer care, she has her loyal customers. This enables her to make enough profit to help her run her home singlehandedly.

Aisha hopes to expand and have a much bigger restaurant in the same location plus have another branch so that she can save to build a decent residential home for her children. She needs a loan to help buy more foodstuffs for her business.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Chanra

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanra L., age 29, and her husband, Mr. Sokha Um, age 34 have been married since 1998 and have two children, one son and one daughter. The children are still young and attend school. The famiL. lives along national road number one about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Chanra has been a tailor for nearL. 10 years. Her husband is a driver. He drives for a company. Chanra is applying for her first loan of $1,000 in order to purchase 3 more sewing machines for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase 3 more sewing machines for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Vy

texts.en:
Mr. Vy M., 34, and his wife, Mrs. Sothea Koem, 32, married in 1997 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of them are in school and the other one is still young. The family lives in a small village off National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Vy has been a mason for 13 years. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. He is requesting his first loan of US$ 500 to purchase a motorcycle to carry construction materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to carry construction materials

loans.name: Mrs. Keom Han Nai Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty people who are all living in Tuol Trea village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Keom Han N. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. They all will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Keom Han N. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivaT. rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Orm Vanna, is a construction worker and he also helps his wife with rice farming. For the rice plantation, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and hire laborers to work in the rice field. With the rest of the loan, she plans to buy fish to raise as a new business and she will also buy fish food to support this business. 

Mrs. Keom Han N. is 28 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the younger one is too yoU. to work or study because that child is only four years old. All of the group members are present in the picture but some of them are blocked. 

Nineteen members in this group have end-of-term loans and other has a monthly payment loan. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and hire laborers to work in the rice field, and buy fish to raise

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora L. is now 55 years old. She is residing in the simple village of Barangay Rio Del Grande in Enrile, Cagayan together with her family. She is a widow and blessed with four children who all graduated from college and are now helping her in managing their welding and repair shop and also their general store. Flora is very proud to have responsible and hard-working children who have finished their studies and become successful in their chosen career. She believes that having them reach their goals in life is the fruit of her sacrifices.

Flora is engaged in a welding and repair shop business. Through her income from her shop, she was also able to put up a sari-sari store (community-based store). She is doing her best to improve her businesses and as much as possible without depending too much on her children because she believes they will also have their own families in the future and it is good for them to start saving money. Despite her age, Flora is still active and showing her strong determination to succeed in her own simple way. All she wants now is to have a sustainable business that will benefit her children and grandchildren someday. For this reason, Flora would like to take out a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP 25,000 as additional business capital.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Noeun's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Noeun S., 69, is a widower with two daughters. One of them is a garment factory worker. The family lives along National Road Number Six about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Noeun has been raising and selling cows for 4 years. Now he is requesting his first loan of US$ 500 to purchase additional cows to raise and sell.

loans.use: To purchase additional cows to raise and sell

loans.name: Harriet's Group

texts.en:
N. Harriet is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a married lady with 4 children, all in school, as she cares for orphans. She has a tailoring business that she has had for 15 years though on a small scale. Her main challenge is the competition from fellow workers and amidst all that, she is able to make 150,000/= worth of profits.

Harriet is a very friendly person and easy to talk to, yet very serious with what she does. She hopes to become a wholesaler of the clothes she makes and also build a residential house for her children. She is happy that together with her husband, she is able to educate her children using her profits. This time, she hopes to increase the capital in her business so that she will be able to make profit and put aside savings for caring for the children and business expansion.

loans.use: Clothing materials for the tailoring business

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en:
The two people shown in the picture here are Mrs. Khoeun S. and her husband. Khoeun S. is a 27-year-old farmer who lives in Pursat Province. She is married to Mr. Moa Tit, age 26, who works with her in the farming business. He also takes time to find firewood in the forest for income.

This couple currently owns a medium-sized stall that they use for raising pigs and cows. During the coming farming season when the heavy rains immediately begin falling down, that is the best time for Khoeun S. to begin growing her crops. Due to their lack of capital, Khoeun S. would like a loan of US$ 1200 from Kiva’s partner HKL. She will be using her loan to buy two cows in order to alleviate her hard labor on the farm and to buy fertilizer and seed for planting. In the future, she proposes to breed her cows for their young.

loans.use: To buy two cows in order to alleviate her hard labor on the farm

loans.name: Mrs. Sokun Chan Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty people who live in Chrouy Slaeng village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sokun C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a vegetable seller in the local market. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to re-sell. She plans to use the rest of the loan to buy an ice-creA. box to conduct a new business. Her husband, Mr. Yang T., is a construction worK. who can make only a meager income to support the family. Mrs. Sokun C. has two children; one is attending the local school, while the other stays at home and helps her in the current business.

Five members in this group loans have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows thE. to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to re-sell and an ice-cream box to conduct a new business

loans.name: Caridad Rosario Mart

texts.en:
Caridad Rosario Mart is happily married to Marvin Scharff, a driver in their community in Mabini Street, Tuguegarao City. They are blessed with two children: Kieren Zen - 4 years old and Kaifer Giovannie - 2 years old. Caridad has been a meat dealer in their village for 3 years already. Aside from that, she also manages to sell cooked foods and some street foods for additional income. She is earning approximately PHP 250 daily that is being used to meet the daily needs of their family. She wants to save money for the future education of her two children thus strives to improve her business.

In this regard, Caridad wants to borrow a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP 7,000 as additional capital. According to Caridad, “Time is Gold” so she spends every minute of her life fruitfully.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan manages a village store located in Rio Del Grande, Enrile, Cagayan. She is already 41 years old and already married for 12 years but unfortunately they do not have any children. For this reason, Susan and her husband adopted her own niece since her parents could no longer support her education. At the moment, Susan strives hard to maintain her store with the assistance of her husband so they can send the child to school.

Her store has been operating for three years. She is thankful that she can continue to maintain it and make the business grow. At present, she is hoping to borrow a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 30,000 as additional capital that she will use for further development in her store. She hopes that she can sustain the business for many years in order to give her family a stable living. She enjoys doing the business and is hoping that someday, she will be able to convert the business into a real grocery store.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Mrs. Phan Surn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phan S. is the group leader of a six-member group, all of whom are living in Sam Raong village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Phan S. is 43 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. P. Thean, is a palm-juice collector who gathers palm juice to process into palm sugar.

Mrs. Phan S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. She now faces a small problem with infertile soil and so she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive. She would use the rest of the loan to buy piglets to raise.

All the people in this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice field and to buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Ban

texts.en:
Mr. Ban B., age 27, and his wife, Mrs. Sien Sun, age 26, live along National Road Number Six about twenty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2001 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Besides his wife and children, Ban also has his parents living with him.

Ban and his wife have been farming for two years. They grow vegetables on farmland near their house and sell to the middlemen who come to buy at their house. Ban is applying for his first loan of $400 to purchase a water-pump and pipes to spray his vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase a water-pump and pipes for growing vegetables

loans.name: So-Eng

texts.en:
Mrs. So-eng M., 29, is a widow with one son. She lives with her mother on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

So-eng has been a silk weaver since she was 15-years old. Her mother is a silk weaver as well. They sell their finished products to a middleman in the village who then sells them in the market in Phnom Penh. 

So-eng is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase silk materials for her and her mother’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
“Success is difficult to achieve for those who fail to try, but is attainable for those who have the courage to try” shares Elsie B., an entrepreneur from Rio del Grande, Enrile, Cagayan.  Elsie is the wife of Glenn, a soldier, and the  industrious mother of a two year old daughter.  

She is an electronic and cell phone load retailer.  She began this business as she wants to help her husband earn a living for their family.  She is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 from Kiva lenders in order to maintain her small business.  Elsie also wants to expand into other business and register as an AVON dealer in order to obtain additional capital and save for the future of their daughter and any other children.

loans.use: To obtain additional capital

loans.name: Soem

texts.en: Soem S. is a 24-year-old farmer who lives in the province of Pursat. She also has handicraft equipment which she uses to weave brooms for sale.  Her husband raises pigs and works on their farm. Soem S. married years ago and is blessed with one young child who is in school. Soem S. wants to grow rice but she lacks the money to do so. Therefore, she is asking for a loan to purchase three sacks of fertilizer and to hire a labourer to plough a piece of her farmland. She will then begin planting a rice crop. She and her husband are pictured in their field.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and to hire a labourer

loans.name: Mr. Chamroeun Sok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people living in Trapeang Chak village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mr. Chamroeun S. is the 42-year-old village bank president. He and his wife, Mrs. Lai Sokkong, are farmers who own a plot of land where they cultivate rice to earn a living. In this plantation, they face an obstacle because they do not have rice seed to cultivate rice on the field. In order to deal with this problem, Mr. Chamroeun S. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer to support the field to make his crop more productive. He has three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory; the other is attending the local school.

Ten members in this group loans are end-of-term borrowers and the other two have monthly payment loans. EoT borrowers are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy rice seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Channarin

texts.en: Mrs. Channarin K. is a villager in Thy Chrab village in TaK. province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. She is a 35 year old widow with two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. She wants to expand her second child’s business. Thus, Mrs. Channarin K. decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery products to earn more profits for her child.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to earn more profits for her child.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey N. lives in Thy Chrab village in Takeo province. She is a farmer and is also a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Brok Rum, is a rice miller who has been hired by the villagers. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn less income to support their household.

In order to improve their lives, Mrs. Srey N. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the rice field and to buy a cow for breeding to earn more income for her family. She is 48 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the rice field and to buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Sarorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarorn S. lives in Prey Mei Lang Thboung village in Takeo province. She is a tailor in her house. She is also a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Pum Vannak, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice.

Now Mrs. Sarorn S. is requesting a loan to buy more piglets for breeding and she would use the rest of the money to purchase fertilizer to support the rice field. She is 28 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding and for fertilizer to support the rice field.

loans.name: Sotheary

texts.en:
Mrs. Sotheary A. is a villager in Tuol Kandal village in the Takeo province. She is a grocer who owns a small business. She is also a farmer who owns a plot of land on which to cultivate rice. For this plantation, she needs some money to hire laborers to work on the field. Her husband, Mr. Huon Khoeun, is a teacher in the local school. 

Mrs. Sotheary A. is 34 years old and the mother of three children, who are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is presented on the right side of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to hire laborers to work on the field

loans.name: Neng

texts.en:
Mrs. Neng C. is a farmer in Kbal Damrei Village in Takeo province. She owns a piece of land on which she grows rice to earn a living. She has some problems on her farm, because of she needs rice seed, fertilizer, and some money to hire laborers to work on the field. To solve these problems, she has decided to ask for a loan. 

Her husband, Mr. Ung Nat, is a construction worker. Mrs. Neng C. is 43 years old and the mother of five children. Two of her children are construction workers and the others attend the local school. Her husband is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work in her field.

loans.name: Bophann

texts.en:
Mrs. Bophann R. was born in 1980. She lives in Chhoeur Neang Khpoh Village in Takeo province. She sells Khmer noodles. 

Her husband, Mr. Reth Vannarith, is a motor taxi driver. He is also a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he grows rice. He faces an obstacle because he does not have enough money to buy rice seed or to plow the field, and he needs fertilizer to support the rice field. Thus, Mrs. Bophann R. has decided to ask for a loan to help her husband's business. 

She is 29 years old and the mother of two children. One of her children is enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support the rice field.

loans.name: Moth

texts.en:
Moth L., 36, is a low-income person living in Siem Reap Province. She is a good and determined single mother who tries to feed her five children, even though she is recently divorced from her husband. She has one married child who lives separately, while the remainder are staying in family home and working in a variety of jobs. 

Moth L. sells fresh fish in the market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, Moth L. goes to a place that is full of fisherman to buy fish in bulk. Then she hurries to bring the fish to the market, which she sells them retail. Because her income is just enough for family’s daily expenses, her house is frequently cracking during the heavy rainy season. To solve this problem, she is requesting a loan of $400 to repair her old house.

loans.use: To repair her old house

loans.name: Sanavar

texts.ru: Санавар Усмонова 1982 года рождения , замужем имеет 2 сына. Торгует на рынке 4 года женским бельем. Бизнес начала еще девочкой, до замужества   торговала на рынке с матерью. Когда вышла замуж сидела почти 2 года дома. Муж был против ее торговли на рынке. Когда он уехал в Россию на заработки ее мать помогала с деньгами. Со временем  уговорила мужа что бы выйти и помогать в торговли матери. Он согласился и  теперь она сама ездит за товаром и привозит с Бишкека и Уратюбе  женскую одежду и белье.  Деньги получает на расширение бизнеса и  увеличение ассортимента.
texts.en:
Born in 1982, Sanavar U. is married and has 2 sons. She has been selling women's undergarments at a market for 4 years. She started her business when she was a girl, prior to the marriage, and sold at the market with her mother. When Sanavar got married, she stayed home for almost 2 years. Her husband was against her selling at the market. When he left to go work in Russia, Sanavar's mother helped with money. With time, Sanavar convinced her husband to let her go and help her mother with the sales. He agreed, and now Sanavar travels for the merchandise by herself and brings women's clothing and undergarments from Bishkek and Uratube. Sanavar is requesting a loan for expanding the business and merchandise selection.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business and merchandise selection expansion

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina is 27 years old. She is divorced with a child who is currently in school. She assumed full responsibility for financing her child’s education when she was divorced by her husband. She owns and operates a dressmaking shop. She sews all forms of female wear with various kinds of styles that suit the taste of her customers, like "kaba" and slit, funeral clothes, dresses, skirts, etc. She wants to use the loan to buy supplies and material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc.  She hopes to raise a good income to provide her daughter with a quality education and be able to support her household adequately.

loans.use: To buy sewing materials

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 29 years old. She is a married mother of three children – two daughters and a son. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a commercial town. She is a hard working woman. She works hard to help her husband take care of the home. Mary runs a grocery shop. She sells groceries such as Milo, sugar, rice, candies, bread, etc. in a store by the street. She has been in business for five years now and wants a loan to buy more groceries to expand her business. Mary says it is her heart's desire to provide her kids a quality education to make them very instrumental in society.

loans.use: To buy more groceries

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en: N. Margaret is a 40-year-old lady and the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is the mother of nine children as she cares for other orphans also in school. She has had a business selling agricultural produce for 10 year. She buys from the farmers in the villages and her main challenge is the scarcity of the farm produce as a result of a bad season. At the start, she had only one type but now has a variety to choose from and sell, hence making about 300,000/= profit per month. She is grateful for the loans and in the future, she plans to have enough so that she can supply her fellow workers. Margaret needs a loan to help increase her stock since this brings in more profits that help to pay school fees and upkeep of her family.

loans.use: To restock her business with more farm produce.

loans.name: Бахтиёр

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

Мирфаёзов Бахтиёр-42 летний мужчина,имеет семью, 4х детей.Занимимается откормом крупного рогатого скота всю свою жизнь.У него ограмный участок земли из 25 гектаров, где он выращивает сельхозкультуру и держит свой скот.Корм для скота он не покупает.Ему помогают егог дети и жена и один работник,которому они платят сельхозкультурой.Год за годом его дело расширяется и в этом году ему не хватило собственных средств и он обратился к нам.Он рад что мы смогли поддержать его и благодарен нам за это.
texts.en:
Bahtijor Mirfajozov is a 42-year-old man with a family, including four children. For his entire life he has earned his living fattening up cattle. He has a very large tract of land, 25 hectares, where he grows crops and raises his cattle. He doesn’t buy the cattle feed. His wife and children help him out, along with one worker whom they pay with crops. His business grows year by year, and this year he didn’t have sufficient resources, so he turned to us. He’s glad we were able to support him and he thanks us for it.

Translated from Russian by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Beny Plus Group

texts.fr: Emma T. 45 ans, est président du groupe « Beny Plus » formé solidairement de 26 membres pour obtenir des crédits de Kiva à travers Hope Kinshasa RDC. Emma avait commencé sa micro-entreprise en 2004 en vendant du café avec un capital initial de $100. Au fil des années, les circonstances l’ont amené a changé l’activité. Aujourd’hui, Emma est vendeur des articles divers dans son quartier périphérique localisé au nord de la ville et le plus peuplé de Kinshasa. En 2008, Il a décidé d’intégrer le groupe « Beny Plus » en vue de réaliser son rêve de devenir grossiste pour fournir des marchandises aux détaillants. Il a reçu trois les crédits de Hope RDC qu’il a remboursés totalement. Le prochain prêt lui servira d’acheter des sacs de lait à revendre pour accroitre le revenu. Présentement, Son activité lui génère un bénéfice de $70 par semaine. La bonne gestion et la réduction des dépenses sont les stratégies utilisées par Emma pour faire prospérer son affaire. Il est marié et père de trois enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 5 et 14 ans. Les deux premiers sont scolarisés.
texts.en:
Emma T., aged 45, is president of the "Beny Plus" group, comprised of 26 members who wish to obtain Kiva loans through Hope Kinshasa RDC. Emma started his coffee-selling microbusiness in 2004 with $100 in capital. Over the years, circumstances pushed him to change his business. Today, Emma sells assorted products in his quarter north of Kinshasa, which is the most populated of all the quarters. In 2008, he decided to begin the "Beny Plus" group to achieve his dream of becoming a wholesaler who supplies products to retailers. He has received three loans from Hope RDC which he repaid in full. The next loan will be used to purchase bags of milk that he will sell to increase his income. Presently, his business generates $70 in profit per week. Good management and reduced spending are the strategies used by Emma to make his business prosper. He is married and has three children whose ages range from 5 to 14 years. The two oldest are in school.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bags of milk to sell so he can increase his income

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is thirty-eight years old. She is a wife and the mother of a child. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oils, etc. She also sells frozen beef, chicken, fish and palm oil as a subsidiary.

She wants to use the loan to buy rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, etc. in bulk to expand her business. She believes in her capacity to finance her child’s education and to better provide her with life opportunities when she improves her income. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is a mother of four children. She is forty-five years old and married. Comfort works hard with the motivation of supporting her children’s education and providing them with a quality of life.

She sells corn dough and Gari. Corn dough is milled maize grain mixed with water and it is used to prepare local meals like banku and porridge. Gari is a cereal made from cassava.

She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of maize to increase her production of corn dough and improve her income to support her kids' education and her household.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 60 year old widow with five children aged between 30 and 45 years.  None of her children goes to school. She resides and owns a two-roomed house where she is staying with six people. Jane doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  There is electricity but no piped water at her home.  The family gets three meals a day.

She resides and works in a semi-urban area selling charcoal in one of Kampala's suburbs.  She uses public transport to go to and from shopping.  Jane sells to an average of 10 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent and feeding the family.  

She has been in this business for the last ten years. Jane has been with MCDT for four years and is servicing her ninth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. Jane is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to own a house in the available plot she bought from previous profits.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 40-year-old married woman who has four children between the ages of 4 and 18 years. All her children go to school. She owns and lives in a four-room house with six people. Margaret doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day. She lives and works in a semi-urban area.

Margaret sells second-hand clothes in one of Kampala's suburbs. She uses public transportation to shop. Margaret sells to an average of 10 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expense is school fees. She has been in this business for eight years. 

Margaret has been with MCDT for nine years and servicing her twentieth loan with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of clothing. Margaret hopes to see her business grow and she wants to own a house on that land that she bought with previous business profits.
 

.

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothes

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 45-year-old married woman with five children aged between 7 and 17 years. All of her children go to school. She owns and lives in a four-room house with seven other people. Margaret takes care of three additional family members/ There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day. She lives and works in a semi-urban area.

Margaret owns a restaurant. She also sells charcoal in one of Kampala's suburbs. She doesn’t incur any extra transportation cost, because she buys from her place of work. Margaret sells to an average of 20 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expense is school fees. She has been in this business for eight years.

Margaret has been with MCDT for nine years and is servicing her twentieth loan with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. Margaret hopes to see her business grow bigger and she wants to own commercial houses in the available space. 

.

loans.use: To buy more rice, cooking oil, bananas, and charcoal

loans.name: Peter Kingori

texts.en:
Peter K. is 57-years-old. He is married to Faith Wanjiru and is the father of five children.

Peter owns a motorbike spare parts shop in Narok that he has been running for three years.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend who is a KADET client. This will be his second loan and he hopes to expand his business from retail to wholesale, and to become a wholesale distributor in Narok. He believes he is a great entrepreneur who can venture into real business once empowered.

loans.use: To increase stock for his motorbike spare parts business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a 25-year-old married woman who has two children ages 4 and 6 years old. All of her children go to school. She owns and lives in a four-room house with five people. Lydia doesn’t take care of any additional family members There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She lives and works in a semi-urban area.

Lydia owns a dry cleaning shop and a video library in one of Kampala's suburbs. She uses public transportation to go shopping. Lydia sells to an average of 10 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and food for her family. She has been in this business for five years. 

Lydia has been with MCDT for four years and is servicing her ninth loan with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more video tapes and buy another flat iron. Lydia wants to see her business grow bigger and she dreams of owning a house on the land that she bought with her business profits.
 

.

loans.use: To buy more video tapes, soap  and a flat iron

loans.name: Fridah Misaro

texts.en:
Fridah G. is 29-years-old. She is married to Mark Gesumu and she is a mother of two school-going children. 

She has a green grocer business that she has been running for the last three years on a busy street in Narok Town.

She learned about KADET from other women who are already registered as clients. This will be her first loan. She is planning to increase her green grocer stock. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to open another shop and create employment for other people.

Her future dream is that she will be able to build her own store and her own house. Fridah also believes she is hard working and she only needs the resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: Increase stock for the green grocer shop such as bananas, tomatotes, kale and Irish potatoes

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a 25-year-old married woman with three children ranging in age from 8 to 14 years. All her children go to school. She rents and lives in a two-room house with five people. Lydia doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She lives and works in a semi-urban area.

Amina owns a restaurant in a Kampala suburb. She uses public transportation to shop. Amina sells to an average of 10 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and food for her family. She has been in this business for five years.

Amina has been with MCDT for four years and is servicing her ninth loan with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more rice, cooking oil, wheat flour, and bananas. Amina hopes to see her business grow and she dreams of owning a house on the land that she bought with her business profits.
 

.

loans.use: To buy more rice, cooking oil, and bananas

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina is a 38-year-old divorced woman who has five children between the ages of 9 and 20 years. All of her children go to school. 

She owns and lives in a two-room house with six other people. Madina doesn’t take care of any additional family members. There is electricity, but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She lives and works in a semi-urban area.

Madina sells charcoal in one of the Kampala suburbs. She uses public transportation to go shopping. Madina sells to an average of 10 people each day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and food for her family. 

She has been in this business for ten years. Madina has been with MCDT for four years and is now servicing her ninth loan with the same group-mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more rice, cooking oil, wheat, flour, sugar, and salt. Madina hopes that her business grow bigger and she dreams of owning a house on the land that she bought with her business profits.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Koffi Missigbeto

texts.fr: Kossi Missigbeto A. est un jeune homme de 25 ans, marié et père d’un enfant.  Il est  coiffeur à Lomé dans le quartier  Vakpo, non loin du carrefour Marigot.  Il sollicite ce crédit pour renforcer son atelier de coiffure par la vente des CD et des appareils électroniques.  Avec ce crédit, il pense augmenter son chiffre d’affaires et de pouvoir subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Kossi Missigbeto A. is a young man of 25, married and the father of one child. He is a barber in the Vakpo district in Lomé, not far from the Marigot crossroads. He is asking for this loan to upgrade his barbershop by selling CDs and electronic apparatus. With this loan, he intends to increase his bottom line and be able to support his family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying CDs and electronic apparatus for resale

loans.name: El Porvenir Group

texts.es:
La Señora Trinidad S. G. de 40 años de edad. Vive con su esposo y mama en una localidad de Veracruz llamada El Porvenir. Esta localidad esta muy cerca del Puerto de Veracruz. Ella es muy conocida en su localidad por ser muy trabajadora y emprendedora.

Doña Trini como la conocen en su localidad  se dedicaba en un inicio a labores de campo junto con su esposo, posteriormente se dedico a la comercializacion de frutas de temporada como lo son el Mango, Zapote Negro, Granada y Ciruela. Sin embargo, este negocio solo es por temporada y es por esto que ella comenzo a comprar y vender cerdos.

Ya lleva 10 años con la compra y venta de cerdos y comenta que le ha hido muy bien ya que con esto a podido tener un mejor nivel de vida.  Soliicitó un credito con Fundacion Realidad ya que tiene pensado invertir en su negocio comprando mas cerdos para vender sus derivados.

Su meta es poder hacer un local para su negocio ya que actualmente lo hace al aire libre y cuando hay mal clima tiene que parar su actividad.

Ella pertenece a un Grupo llamado "El Porvenir" que está formado por otras 9 personas y solicitan un credito de $23,000  los cuales invertiran en sus actividades que son venta de leche, venta de quesos, zapatos, ropa, venta de comida, etc. Todos comparten la meta de mejorar el nivel de vida de sus familias y siguir adelante con sus negocios.
texts.en:
Trinidad S. G. is 40-years-old. She lives in Veracruz with her husband and mother in a town called El Porvenir, which is very close to the Port of Veracruz. She is quite well known in her area because she is so hard-working and enterprising. Doña Trini, as she’s known in her town, started out as a farm worker with her husband, and later earned her living selling seasonal fruits like mangos, black sapote, pomegranates, and plums. That’s only a seasonal business, though, so she started buying and selling pigs, which she’s been doing for 10 years. She says it’s been a really good business because it has allowed her to achieve a higher standard of living. She requested a loan from Fundación Realidad because she plans to invest in her business by purchasing more pigs so she can sell the pork products. Her goal is to be able to have her own store, since she currently sells in the open air and has to shut down when the weather is bad. Doña Trini belongs to a group called “El Porvenir”, along with 9 other people. They are seeking a loan for 23,000 pesos to invest in their businesses, which include sales of milk, cheese, shoes, clothing, food, etc. They all share the goal of improving their families’ standard of living and getting ahead with their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pigs so she can sell pork products

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 57 year old father of four who owns a grocery store in the southern town of Tyre. He has had the store for two years and is requesting a loan of $1,300 to buy inventory for his store - namely food products. Ali's clients are mostly neighbors and other residents of the town. This is Ali's third cycle with Al Majmoua - when he first opened the store he found promoting it to attract clients difficult. However, the previous two loans he acquired from Al Majmoua have helped him improve his store and increased his determination to further expand it. Ali has a passion for running his own business and it is this passion that will drive him to further expand his business ventures.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for the store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy products for the store.

loans.name: Najat

texts.en: Najat is a 61 year old married woman with one child. She has been working in the agriculture sector as a farmer since 1994. Over the years, thanks to her business income, she has been able to meet her family's needs in collaboration with her husband. Today, Najat is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy agricultural merchandise so she can increase her income.

loans.use: To buy agricultural merchandise

loans.name: Aliya

texts.en: Aliya is a 30 year old grocery store owner who lives in the southern coastal town of Tyre in Lebanon. Her customers are neighbors and residents of the town. Aliya is the only person in her family capable of running the store and this is the first time she has applied for a loan with Al Majmoua. She will use the loan to help educate her nephew. Her goal is to continue to expand the store.

loans.use: To help educate her nephew.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled is a 40 year old married man and father of 3 children. He has owned a butcher shop since 2007 and has 15 years of experience in this field. Today, Khaled is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy a new machine for his shop in order to better satisfy the needs of his clients.

loans.use: To buy a new machine.

loans.name: Wifak

texts.en:
Wifak J. lives in Southern Lebanon where she owns a store in which she sells clothes and shoes. Her clients are friends, neighbors and tourists.  

This is her first loan from Al Majmoua and she is requesting $2000 to buy more products. She faces increased competition in her area, but she distinguishes her store by selling unique, high quality goods. Her dream is to expand her store and improve her business.

loans.use: Shoes and clothes for the store

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 46-year-old married man who lives with his wife and 4 children. Four months ago, he decided to open a vegetable shop using his 10 years of experience in this field. Hussein is applying for a loan of $1,000 to buy more merchandise so he can increase his sales and income.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Amira

texts.en: Amira is a 30-year-old single woman who lives with her parents. She has owned a clothes shop called "Amira" since 2005 where she earns income to help satisfy the needs of her family. Today, Amira is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase additionA. clothes for the shop so she can satisfy the heavy demands of the market and help increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothes

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 28-year-old single man who lives with his family. He has owned a car repair shop since 2005. He started his business, along with his brother, to improve his parents' living conditions. Today, Mohamad is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy new tools to better satisfy the needs of his clients.

loans.use: To buy new tools

loans.name: Georgette

texts.en: Georgette is a 40-year-old married woman and the mother of 2 children. In 1990, she decided to help her husband in the household by working as a home-based tailor. After this long experience, Georgette is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a new sewing machine to satisfy the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Wahid

texts.en: Wahid is a 60-year-old married man with 3 children. He has owned a food market for the past 12 years. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his children's needs. Today, Wahid is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a new refrigerator and renovate his shop in order to attract more clients and increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase a new refrigerator and renovate his shop

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 26-year-old married man and father of 2 young children. He has owned a car repair shop since 2000 to earn income to improve his family's living conditions. Today, Mohamad is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy more spare car parts to better satisfy the needs of his clients.

loans.use: To buy more car spare parts

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.es:
Eugenia es socia del Banco Comunal Amauta.
Eugenia es conviviente, tiene 44 años y 4 hijos, Eugenia tiene un kiosco ubicado cerca de un terminal terrestre, en donde vende productos variados como linternas, golosinas, pilas, artículos de aseo, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Eugenia necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de linternas y cepillos.
Los sueños de Eugenia son tener una tienda grande y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Eugenia is a member of the village bank "Amauta."

Eugenia is 44 years old, has four children, and lives with her partner. Eugenia has a kiosk located near the ground terminal where she sells various products like flashlights, candy, batteries, and toiletries where she works every day.

Eugenia needs a loan of 600 soles that she will invest in buying flashlights and brushes.

Eugenia's dreams are to have a large store and to provide a good education to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying flashlights and brushes

loans.name: Zenaida Julia

texts.es:
Zenaida es socia del Banco Comunal Amauta.
Zenaida es casada, tiene 46 años y 7 hijos, Zenaida vende billeteras, lapiceros, entre otros productos, actividad que realiza de manera ambulatoria en las calles céntricas de la ciudad de Ayacucho, además Zenaida vende ropa en la feria de las Américas, actividad que realiza los días domingos.
Zenaida necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de chompas y polos.
Los sueños de Zenaida son educar a sus hijos y tener una tienda de ropa.
texts.en:
Zenaida is a member of the village bank "Amuata."

Zenaida is married, 46 years old, and has 7 children. Zenaida peddles wallets and pencils among other products on the central streets in the city of Ayacucho. Also, Zenaida sells clothing in the market known as "la feria de las Américas" on Sundays.

Zenaida needs a loan of 1000 soles that she will invest in buying sweaters and shirts.

Zenaida dreams are to educate her children and have a clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sweaters and shirts

loans.name: Josefa

texts.es:
Josefa es socia del Banco Comunal Amauta.
Josefa es casada, tiene 40 años y 3 hijos, Josefa vende leña en su casa, la leña lo adquiere en los diferentes pueblos de la región, además Josefa junto a su esposo tienen un carro con el cual realizan transporte de carga.
Josefa necesita un préstamo de 3500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de leña y para cambiar los neumáticos de su carro.
Josefa sueña con que sus hijos culminen sus estudios y sean profesionales y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Josefa is a member of the village bank "Amauta."

Josefa is married, 40 years old, and has three children. Josefa sells firewood from her house, which she obtains in various towns of the region. Additionally, Josefa and her husband have a car which they use to transport cargo.

Josefa needs a loan of 3500 soles to invest in buying wood and changing the tires of her car.

Josefa's dreams are that her children finish their studies and can become professionals and to expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy firewood and change the tires on her car

loans.name: Carolina Raquel

texts.es:
Raquel es socia del Banco Comunal Amauta.
Raquel es soltera y tiene 43 años, Raquel tiene una tienda en casa de sus padres en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, frutas, bebidas, carnes, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Raquel necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de bebidas.
Los sueños de Raquel son salir adelante con su negocio y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Raquel is a member of the Amauta Community Bank. She is 43 years old and single. Raquel has a shop in her parents home where she sells general grocery items, such as vegetables, fruits, drinks and meats, and she works there every day. Raquel is requesting a loan of 1000 soles (approximately $350), which she plans to use to purchase drinks. Raquel's dreams are to keep making progress and expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beverages

loans.name: Elsa Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elsa es socia del Banco Comunal Amauta.
Elsa es soltera, tiene 39 años y 2 hijos, Elsa vende comida, sus ventas los realiza ambulatoriamente, lo lleva al colegio Guaman Poma, además Elsa vende comida en la puerta de su casa por las noches, Elsa tiene proyectado iniciar con la venta de golosinas.
Elsa necesita un préstamo de 1250 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de golosinas.
Los sueños de Elsa son prosperar su negocio y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Elsa is a member of the Amauta Community Bank. She is a single 39-year-old mother of two children. She sells food outdoors at the Guaman Poma school and also out of her home in the evenings. Elsa plans to start selling snacks and is requesting a loan of 1250 soles (approximately $450) to purchase products. Elsa's dreams are to prosper with her business and for her children to be successful.
