Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock her business with more merchandise

loans.name: Marilee

texts.en:
Marilee is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders to further support her parents in their medical and basic necessities. She is still single at the age of 24 and she is presently living in her parents' house located in Barangay Madiangat Quezon Nueva Vizcaya. She has finished her studies in college but due to a lack of job opportunities, she volunteered to be a church worker in their simple village while running a sewing business at the same time.

Aside from her honorarium for being a church worker, she wanted to have a sideline to earn additional income. She is planning to be a retailer of gasoline in their Barangay (township) but she does not have sufficient capital. When she was informed about the programs and services of ASKI and Kiva loans, she felt encouraged to join and ask for additional capital to maintain her sewing business, still hoping that eventually, she would be able to start up her plan of gasoline retailing in their village.

Marilee is very happy to have her business because it is of great help to her family and makes her proud of herself for its success. She hopes to become even more successful someday and somehow to uplift her family’s poor living situation.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia A., 33 years old, hails from the island village in the town of Binagonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is married to Willardo and mother to two boys. She is a very industrious and hard-working mother. Her dream is to bring her family out of poverty.

With her determination to rise above poverty, Cecilia joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and now KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2004. With her membership in ASHI, she hoped to have capital for her planned business. Her previous loans were used to pay for fishing gear that they sell to fishermen. Just year ago, she shifted her business into having her own fish cage, where she raised fish until ready to harvest and sell at the market. She noticed that this business is more productive than her previous one.

Just recently, Cecilia is requesting a loan of 25,000 pesos as additional capital for her fish-cage business. Specifically, to pay for 2 bundles of nets, 30 pieces bamboos, fingerlings worth 5,400 pesos and to pay for labor and food for the laborer.

Cecilia is hopeful that she can reach her dreams in the near future, considering that ASHI and KIVA are giving her trust and confidence. She dreams of having a bigger fish-cage, sending her children to school, and also repairing her house so it is more spacious and more durable.

loans.use: To pay for 2 bundles of nets, 30 pieces bamboos, fingerlings worth 5,400 pesos

loans.name: Mao's Group

texts.en:
There are four low-income people who are jointly requesting this group loan. Their leader, Mr. Mao S., 24, is a single man who drives a motor taxi to earn a living. He currently lives with his elderly mother who sells a few grocery items for income. Mao S. will be using his loan to add to his meager savings to replace his old taxi that is not attractive to customers.

The other borrowers are:

Mr. V., a fisherman, who is requesting a loan to buy nets for fishing;

Mrs. C. who will be using the loan to decorate and repair her old house; and

Mrs. T. who makes a living fishing and is looking for a loan to add more fishing gear.

loans.use: To replace his old taxi that is not attractive to customers

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia (or Amy as she is called in their village) is a resident of Barangay Maddiangat Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. Due to lack of financial resources, she was not able to finish her college education and instead started to work and help her parents earn a living.

She is married to Fernando and they have three children. Two of them are high school graduates and and presently working as a welder and a saleslady in Solano while the youngest is still studying in high school. They want their youngest child to pursue his college education and hope he will have a stable job.

At present, Amelia and her husband are helping one another in supporting the needs of their family through their farming and sewing businesses. She also accepts clothes for repair for additional income. She is now in need of additional business capital amounting to PHP 5,000. She intends to use the loan to buy the necessary materials for her sewing business. She hopes that Kiva lenders will grant her request so she can dream of achieving her goals in life.

loans.use: business improvement

loans.name: Gulsaada's Group

texts.en:
Here is a story about Gulsaada, a fifty-three-year-old widow, who is the leader of this group. Having raised three sons, she still lives with two of them. Gulsaada married off her eldest son and now he lives separately. Her second son works in a local market, whereas her youngest son still goes to school. As for herself, Gulsaada is engaged in raising, feeding, and resale of cattle. This activity enables her to provide for the family's needs. Her youngest son, apart from going to school, also helps her look after the cattle.

After buying two sheep for about ninety dollars, six years have passed during which keeping cattle has been their main source of income. They have even saved enough money to buy a big TV and a fridge. Currently they are keeping a cow, two calves and four sheep. All this allows them to make seventy dollars a month. Gulsaada would really be happy if she were able to get a loan as she needs some funds to be able to buy three or four sheep.

Aigerim, Rustam, and Alina are Gulsaada’s partners. In spite of their young age they are already making their first adult steps toward accomplishing their plans. Aigerim, 23, is engaged in selling flowers. She has a decent income, namely around US$ 360, so her plan is to lease another flower shop for about US$ 170, and equip it.

Rustam, 19, is unmarried. He sells foodstuffs: vegetables, soft drinks, milk products, and also detergents. He started business at ten years of age. Now he earns US$ 360-400 a month. He would be happy to obtain a loan to purchase a certain amount of potatoes, onions, carrots, cabbage, tomatoes, cucumbers and soft drinks.

Alina, 20, is also unmarried. She is occupied with selling foodstuffs, candies, cakes, etc. She started business about a year ago when her mother bought her a small shop. Now Alina’s monthly income is US$ 300-360. She needs a loan to purchase tobacco products and soft drinks.

====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy three or four sheep

loans.name: Medarda Elizabeth

texts.es: Medarda Elizabeth R. R. reside en el municipio de Colon ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad. Medarda cuenta con 25 años de edad vive con su esposo y su pequeña hija Andrea de 3 años de edad, William esposo de Madarda es empleado y aporta a la familia $200.00 US mensuales. Medarda posee una sala de belleza hace siete años la cual ha ido creciendo y ganando popularidad en la zona ahora Medarda a surtido su sala de belleza con productos para el cabello de esta manera logra generar más ingresos para la familia, ahora ella a tomado la decisión de solicitar un crédito ya que sus ventas y demanda en su productos ha ido aumentando y desea comprar variedad de productos nuevos para surtir su  negocio.
texts.en:
Medarda Elizabeth R. R. lives in the town of Colon, located in the district of La Libertad. She is 25 years old and lives with her husband and young daughter Andrea, who is 3 years old. Her husband William is employed and earns $200 USD each month for their family.

For seven years, Medarda has been operating a beauty salon that is growing and gaining popularity in the area. She now needs to restock her salon with hair products so that she can generate more income for her family. Since her sales and the demand for her merchandise have been increasing, Medarda decided to apply for a loan so that she can buy a variety of new products to sell at her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products to restock her salon

loans.name: Myrliza

texts.en:
“Put God first in everything you do and He will pour out His blessings unto you” is a very nice quotation that gives encouragement to Myrliza in her everyday life. She is married to Lito and they are living a simple life in the rural community of Barangay Maddiangat Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. The couple do not have any children but they are not losing hope and still waiting for the right time.

Myrliza manages a small general store in their village. However, her income is not enough to meet the needs of their family. With her desire to make her business grow, she is now requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional business capital. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise and some stock that is very much in demand. Aside from her store, she also buys and sells recyclable materials for extra income. She knows that through her own business strategies and with the assistance of Kiva lenders, her business will someday become truly successful.

loans.use: additional capital for her general store and her recycling

loans.name: Paul Mutie

texts.en:
Paul Mutie is 46 years old, and he is married with two children, a son and a daughter. He lives in Kangemi, Nairobi.

He was introduced to KADET by his friends and he has never borrowed from other sources. This will be his fourth loan with KADET.

Kangemi is a highly populated area but has few computer colleges, hence Paul stands a high chance of succeeding in this kind of business.

Paul intends to equip the school with new and up-to-date computers and printers as this will enable him to attract and admit more students thus giving him a cutting edge in the competitive market.

loans.use: Buying better computers and one printer for the school

loans.name: Stephen Kinyanjui

texts.en:
Stephen K. is 28 years old and married with one child. His runs their business together with his wife Jackline in the busy Uthiru area.

He got to know about KADET through his friend and he had never borrowed from other sources before. He will now be servicing his third loan.

He plans to stock a wide range of clothes as well as shoes so as to meet his customers' needs and requests. This will also distinguish his business from the rest and hence give him the upper hand.

loans.use: Buying more clothes so as to increase profitability

loans.name: Tu

texts.en:
Tu L. is 39 years old, a married woman and good mother caring for six children; five of them are students and live in the family home and the other one is married and lives separately.

Tu L. sells fish meatballs in Psa Kroam Market, a big and good location of Siem Reap Province. She usually makes an income of US$ 3 per day to help support the family's meager living conditions. Additionally, her husband always uses his own motorbike for providing a taxi service. It is often hard for Tu L. to cook meals because she doesn’t have a kitchen inside her home. She hopes to build a small kitchen by using a loan from HKL.

loans.use: To build a small kitchen

loans.name: Tilebubu's Group

texts.en:
Tilebubu is this group’s leader.  Though she is forty-seven and has a husband, who provides for the family by raising cattle, Tilebubu has always preferred to live an active life for her part and not just stay at home. She is one of those rare women who manage to combine family duties with work. 

Tilebubu  has raised three children. Her eldest daughter lives separately and her other daughter and son go to college and high school respectively. As to Tilebubu’s occupation, she wakes early in the morning and heads toward Alamudun market, where she purchases meat, mainly lamb and beef; and innards: intestines, stomach, etc. wholesale and resells them in Kant and Tokmok cities. This brings in US$ 190 a month, a significant contribution to family budget. 

Seeing her efforts and being aware of what hard work it is, her husband and son strive to help her. As an achievement Tilebubu’s family has finally bought a car! They have also built some facilities around the house. Tilebubu does not want to stop at that. She is keen to obtain a loan to purchase shoes and invest more money on buying innards. This loan would be helpful to repair their car. 

Tilebubu has a pretty experienced team of partners. They are Aina (52), Doorhan (23), Edilbek (47) and Marifat (53). 

Aina is a widow. She works as a chief inspector in an HR office. She also sells strawberries and raspberries from her garden. Aina has got interested in keeping cattle, and hopes to get a loan to purchase one cow, one calf and two sheep. 

Doorhan is married. She manufactures national bed clothing and bakes pastries. Doorhan needs a loan to purchase a calf, two sacks of flour and other ingredients for baking, as well as to purchase some fabric for the bedding. 

Edilbek is a musician. He also organizes cultural activities and concerts for disabled people. He needs a loan for car repair. Otherwise it is going to be difficult to carry all his instruments. 

Marifat sells vegetables at a local market. She wants to obtain a loan to buy 660 pounds of grapes. 

======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase shoes and animal innards to sell

loans.name: Mola Tubariki Group

texts.en:
Mauufe is a member of the Mola Tubariki borrower group,she is 41 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children,Her children are aged 26,20 and 15 years.

Mauufe started her own cafe business selling food 6 years ago,she works 12 hour a day and earn mothly profit approximeatrly 100,000 Tsh.

This is Maaufe second loan from BRAC.She requested the amount of 450,000 in order to buy more rice,sugar wheat etc for her business.

With the additional profit she gain from the use of this loan Mauufe hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Burda is also a member of the same borrower group she requested loan amount 200,000 in order to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more rice,sugar,

loans.name: Huth's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan for four women who live in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Mrs. Huth H., age 52, has been selected to be the group leader by the other members. Huth H. has been a domestic fish catcher for eleven years. She also goes with her other neighbors who are fishermen to fish in and around Tunle Sap Lake. She can fish over 5 kilos a day, for which she earns $1.50 per kilo. To help feed the family a little more, her husband drives a motor taxi. The family has seven children; one is married, and the others go to work and to school. Recently, Huth’s fishing operation has been declining due to a lack of tools. Because of this, she would like a loan to increase the quantity of her fishing equipment and to repair her broken tools.

About the other three borrowers who are jointly taking this loan:

H. will use her loan to buy a machine to connect to her existing boat for fishing. N., a local fish catcher, is looking for a loan to buy nets and traps. N. is applying for a loan to repair a portion of her broken house.

loans.use: To increase the quantity of fishing equipment and to repair broken tools

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes Arambuloo, who lives in the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal Province in the Philippines, is a woman of courage who maintains hope in her ability to rise above poverty. Happily married to Felix, a 37-year-old fisherman and her business partner, she is a mother to three boys and a girl.

Lourdes joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 1999, and during her ten years as a member of ASHI, she has been noted for her exemplary performance in meeting her obligations in the organization. Her previous loans were carefully used as rolling capital for her fishing business. Because fishing allows her to earn just enough income for her family needs, she recently ventured into raising pigs, an enterprise that will bring her enough profit to save for the future of her children. Fishing will now become her secondary business.

She is now requesting her ninth loan, 45,000 pesos to pay for 10 piglets, 26 sacks of assorted feeds, vitamins and transportation expenses. Lourdes is hopeful that the trust and opportunity given by ASHI and KIVA, coupled with hard work, will allow her to reach her dreams of expanding her business, sending her children to school, and building a new and more spacious house.

loans.use: To pay for 10 piglets, 26 sacks of assorted feeds, vitamins and transportation expenses.

loans.name: Ayuba

texts.en:
Ayuba R. is currently in the business of brewing and selling alcohol and is requesting a loan to open up a bar. Ayuba is 47 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: open up a bar

loans.name: Atyrkul's Group

texts.en:
Atyrkul is thirty-eight years old. Being a mother to three sons, she lives the humble life of a shepherd’s wife. Twenty years ago, her husband inherited some cattle from his parents and since then, he has been raising cattle and working as a shepherd.

Atyrkul, being a housewife, takes care of the household. She also actively helps her husband look after their cattle. Her daily routine begins with milking cows in the morning, then selling the milk to her neighbors. Besides cows, they keep some other livestock, too. So, Atyrkul has always a lot to do around the house.

Having lived all her life in a rural area, she decided to send her eldest son to college, to live in the city. Two other sons live at home and help their parents. By selling some of their livestock, they managed to buy a house, though Atyrkul’s monthly income from selling milk is just US$ 65.

Now, Atyrkul is desperate to buy another cow. One more cow means more milk for sale, consequently more daily income to save for their second son’s education. For villagers every liter of milk is valuable, since it brings cash, which is a rare thing in a village area.

Here are Atyrkul’s partners: Amanbu, Altyn and Nazira. Amanbu is fifty. With her husband she keeps livestock: one cow and twenty sheep. Her husband is an electrician, but Amanbu, being a housewife, meets her daily needs by selling milk. Now, Amanbu wants to get a loan to buy a calf and with the rest of the loan she would purchase sheep for fattening and resale.

Altyn is twenty-five. She is married and has three children. To help her husband, who is a welder, she sells foodstuffs and earns US$ 130. She needs a loan to include more vegetables, fruit, and salads in her assortment.

Nazira is twenty-three. She is not married yet. However, for five years already she has lived independently in terms of finances, as she has been selling newspapers, magazines and some detergents. Nazira needs a loan to open a small shop to sell detergents out of.

====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy a milk cow to sell milk

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
“A man of perseverance will bring success to his family"; this is the inspiring quotation of Emilia. Iya (as she is called in their village) finished her secondary education and is happily married to Eugene who works as a carpenter. They are blessed with three children, presently studying in high school and elementary level.

Emilia is engaged in the duck-raising business. She also engaged in vegetable vending for additional income. She wants to develop her business into a more progressive one for them to uplift their life from poverty and to be able to further support the education of their children. With this goal in mind, she is now asking for financial assistance amounting to PHP 5,000. This amount will be of big help in maintaining her business.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Bibi Ziba Group

texts.en: Bibi Ziba is the group leader of the Bibi Ziba Group. There are two members in this group. Each of them wants a loan to improve their business and make it larger. They are requesting a group loan of 28000 Afghani. Bibi Ziba wants a loan for her husband who has a general store. Bibi Jan wants a loan her tailoring business. They are very happy about this loan process being offered in Afghanistan.

loans.use: For expanding business

loans.name: Chhath

texts.en:
P. was born in 1981; she is a married woman and blessed with one lovely child who is minor and still not enrolled in school. P.'s husband's name is Thit, 20, and he works in construction.

P. has built a pigpen next to her house where she raises many pigs to earn a living. On the other hand, she also takes time to work on the farm. Soon the farming season is coming; she proposes to plant a rice crop, using a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed for growing.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed for growing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more milk in bulk

loans.name: Cholpon's Group

texts.en:
This is Cholpon, the leader of this group. She is 38 years old. Her husband is raises livestock. They have three children. Their son and daughter are 19 and 17 respectively and the smallest child is just 3 years old. Apart from taking care of her baby, Cholpon keeps a cow and sells its milk to purchasers. Cholpon’s brother, working in Russia, once sent her money, with which she was able to buy five cows. Gradually she and her husband saved enough money to pay Cholpon’s brother back. This is due to their 20-year experience in cattle breeding. Raising livestock, Cholpon and her husband have been able to buy some furniture for their house as well as some household equipment. Now, they need to obtain a loan. With this loan they would get an opportunity to purchase calves to send to mountain pastures, keep them and then resell after bringing them back. They want to increase the total population so that after selling some of the livestock they would be able to pay for their son’s education. 

Here is Cholpon’s team: Asilbek, Kadicha and Halima. Asilbek, 44, rents a piece of land, where he grows watermelons, onions, tomatoes and cucumbers. Farming helps him provide for his wife and five children. Now he is in need of a loan to purchase fertilizers to grow more crops.

Kadicha, 49, is married and has raised seven children! Most of her children have gone to Russia for work. As for Kadicha, she sells vegetables: onions, potatoes and carrots. Kadicha needs a loan as she wants to begin selling fruit and thus expand her offerings. She also requests this loan to buy a calf.

Halima, 26, is married and has one child. Her husband does odd jobs at a construction site, whereas she keeps two cows and sells milk and yogurt. They want to increase the amount of milk for sale by buying one more cow. To do that, the only way is to get a loan. They have already built a new shed for that. 

======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept -- People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase calves for breeding to sell later

loans.name: Fwazi Group

texts.en: Fwazi is the leader of the Fwazi Group. There are four members in this group. Each member wants a loan to expanding his/her business. They are requesting a group of loan 40000 Afghani. Fwazi wants a loan for her tailoring business. A. Fahim and Shbana each want a loan for their general stores. S. Hassam wants a loan for his taxi. They are very thankful to Kiva lenders who support all poor people.

loans.use: For business progress

loans.name: Lok

texts.en:
Mrs. Lok N., 41, and is married to Phin Koeun who is 37. They currently live in Siem Reap Province.

Lok N. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also cultivates a rice crop, while her husband works as a local building worker. They have two teenage children who attend school. Lok N. will be using a loan to purchase a cow which she will use to help alleviate her hard labor in the farming business, and she will also rent out her cow to other farmers for additional income.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Easter

texts.en:
Easter P. is currently in the business of selling goods like cooking oil, soap, body lotion, etc., in an open place and is requesting a loan to build up a shop. Easter is 30 years old and is married with a husband who works as a driver. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy more goods in her shop to sell.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a shop

loans.name: Juan Antonio

texts.es: Juan Antonio C. de 51 años de edad reside en departamento de La Libertad junto a su esposa quien trabaja como comerciante y su pequeño nieto Jesús. Juan posee un pequeño negocio ubicado en su casa donde vende granos básicos y producen tortillas para vender todas las tardes, con cuatro años de experiencia Juan apuesta a ampliar sus ventas surtiendo su negocio con mayor cantidad de granos básicos es por eso que hoy solicita un crédito para cumplir sus metas y sobre todo generar mayores ingresos para darles seguridad y apoyo a su familia.
texts.en:
Juan Antonio C. is 51. He lives in the La Libertad department with his wife and small grandson, Jesús. His wife is a business woman. Juan has a small business located in his house. He sells basic grains and produces tortillas to sell every afternoon. He has four years of experience, and he intends to increase his sales and stock his store with a larger quantity of basic grains. That is why he is now asking for a loan to reach his goals. Above all, he wants to generate greater income to give his family security and support.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock his business

loans.name: Lea Esmeralda

texts.es: Lea Esmeralda C. B. reside en Colon municipio del departamento de La Libertad. Lea vive con su padre, hermanas, y  su madre quien le ayuda en el negocio. Lea tiene 25 años de edad es una mujer muy trabajadora y de fe en Dios, Lea ayuda a sus padres por medio de su negocio ubicado en su casa una tienda de productos de consumo, pero como que no fuese suficiente trabajo Lea también se dedica a la confección de ropa a la medida, elabora todo tipo de vestuario para damas, el crédito que solicita Lea es para invertirlo en la tienda surtiéndolo de cereales, bebidas y boquitas, para lograr obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Lea Esmeralda C. B. lives in the Colon municipality in the La Libertad department. Lea lives with her father, sisters, and mother; who she helps with the business. Lea is 25, and she is a very hard working woman with faith in God. Lea helps her parents in their business, which is located in their house. Their store sells consumable items. As if this was not enough work, Leah also makes custom clothes. She makes every type of clothing for women. The loan Lea is asking for is to invest in the store and stock it with grains, drinks, and snacks in order to get greater income.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Reebok Group

texts.en:
Joha M., age 48, is a divorcee with three children who are ages 22, 20 and 18 years. She has a clothing shop. She has had this shop for about ten years now.  She works from 9am to 6pm daily and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $.123. 

This will be Joha’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase the stock by buying more clothes for sell and has paid the loans back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to increase her stock even more.

Joha will share this loan with subgroup A of the Reebok group. The subgroup has five members, who run cafes an  salons, and sell cosmetics and vegetables. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, she is the first on the left in a blue dress.

loans.use: To increase the stock of clothing for her clothing shop

loans.name: Consorcia

texts.en:
Consorcia V. is a 57-year-old strong woman from the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is widowed and was left with four children to take care of. Her children were still young when her husband passed away. Now they are are all of legal age.

In 1995, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with hopes of having access to capital to start a business. Her previous loans were prudently utilized as rolling capital on her business of basket making made from bamboo. The business was tiring, laborious and time consuming considering her age. That is why, just recently, she shifted and ventured into a new business: the resale of charcoal and dressed chicken.

Now on her tenth loan, she requests loan of 45,000 pesos as additional capital for her primary business of reselling charcoal and dressed chicken. Specifically, the loan will use to pay for 200 sacks of charcoal and 100 kilos of dressed chicken plus labor and transportation expenses.

She is hopeful that her business will grow and may have space in the market. She also dreams of helping her grandchildren in their school fees and to save for her youngest daughter since she is a special child.

loans.use: To pay for 200 sacks of charcoal and 100 kilos of dressed chicken

loans.name: Nasjwa

texts.en:
Nasjwa N. is currently in the business of selling cakes and bread and is requesting a loan to open up a bakery.  Nasjwa is 18 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land, build and rent it out.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open up a bakery

loans.name: Francisca Cristina

texts.es: Francisca Cristina D. D. G. resiD. en Colon municipio del departamento D. La Libertad. Mujer casada con 54 años D. edad, y madre D. un niño. Francisca y su esposo se apoyan económicamente Jose trabaja como comerciante y genera un aproximado D. $200.00 US mensuales los que destina para los gastos D. la familia y Francisca se dedica a su negocio una tienda ubicada en su domicilio donD. posee una clientela muy estable por que manifiestan sus clientes que Francisca es una persona honrada y amable con ellos. Francisca  solicita un crédito para surtir su negocio con lo que lograra generar mayores ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
Francisca Cristina lives in Colon, a county in the state of La Libertad. She is married, 54 years old, and has one son. Francisca and her husband help each other financially. Jose works in retail and generates approximately $200.00 US dollars per month which he uses to pay for household's expenses. Francisca has a convenience store at her home which already has stable customers who express Francisca is an honest and friendly person with them. Francisca is asking for this loan to replenish her store's stock to generate more income for the family.

Translated from Spanish by Linda Zamora, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replenish store stock

loans.name: Reina Margarita

texts.es: Reina Margarita H. A. reside en el municipio de Apopa en el departamento de San Salvador. Reina vive en casa propia solamente con su esposo. Reina siempre tuvo el sueño de instalar su propio negocio y tras muchos años de ahorros y créditos otorgados ha estabilizado una panadería con cinco años de experiencia, donde se produce variedad de pan dulce y la mejor quesadilla de Apopa, posee una clientela muy extensa por la calidad que solo el pan de Reina tiene, ahora ella solicita un crédito para compra de materia prima que le permita aumentar su producción en pan dulce  y así seguir consolidando mas su panadería.
texts.en:
Reina Margarita H. A. lives in the Apopa municipality in the San Salvador department. Reina lives in her own house with her husband. Reina always had the dream of setting up her own business. After many years of savings and loans, she established her bakery. She has five years of experience, and she makes a variety of sweet breads and the best quesadilla in Apopa. She has quite a lot of customers because of the quality that only Reina’s bread has. She is now asking for a loan to buy raw materials. This will allow her to increase her production of sweet breads and to continue strengthening her bakery.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw materials

loans.name: Levica

texts.en:
Levica and her husband, Leonardo, are living in the simple village of Madiangat Quezon Nueva Vizcaya with their five children. They help each other to support the education of their children through their buy and sell business of recyclable materials.  

Despite the hardships of life, they are determined to become successful in their business endeavor. Aside from collecting scrap materials that they will sell in the junk shop, Levica also sells charcoal at retail price in the market of Solano. Every day her husband looks for scrap materials and sells them in big junk shops in Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She can see that their small businesses are doing good and are very beneficial to their family. Thus, she wants to request additional capital amounting to PHP 5,000 for the improvement of her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to improve her businesses (buying and selling of recyclable material and charcoal)

loans.name: Ronald Gerardo

texts.es: Ronald Gerardo B. G. de 29 años de edad reside en el municipio de Cuscatancingo en el departamento de San Salvador. Ronald vive con su esposa y sus tres hijas Telma de 7 años, Fátima de 4 años y la pequeña Melisa de tan una año de edad. Ronald es el único proveedor y sustento económico para la familia. Ronald es empleado de una distribuidora de bebidas en El Salvador cuenta con 12 años de experiencia en las ventas de las misma, el deseo de Ronald es comprar  bebidas para  montar  un pequeño deposito y  poder distribuirlas de manera ambulante en la zona de Apopa y Soyapango de esta manera Ronald podrá obtener ingresos extras que serán de gran soporte económico para su familia, y es por ello que hoy solicita este crédito.
texts.en:
Ronald Gerardo B. G. is 29 years old and lives in the town of Cuscatancingo in the district of San Salvador. Ronald lives with his wife and three daughters: Telma (age 7), Fátima (age 4), and little Melisa (age 1). He is the sole provider and only source of financial support for his family.

Ronald is employed by a soft drink distributor in El Salvador and has 12 years of experience in sales. He wants to purchase soft drinks so that he can set up a small warehouse and be able to distribute his products door-to-door in the Apopa and Soyapango neighborhoods. For this reason, Ronald has requested a loan so that he will able to generate extra income to support his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soft drinks to sell door-to-door

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her farming activities

loans.name: 26 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Lý N. Thị is a 57-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hóa. Lý is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 26 Nam Ngạn (17.09.26).

Lý is married and has three adult children.  To making a living, Lý works in a family member's business running a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling assorted food and snacks in the local community. Lý has been in this business for over two years and earns approximately 1.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2008, Lý joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Lý has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1.963.500 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business further. The loan will be the thirrd loan taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Lý plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  H. Thị H. Hương is a 30-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her  tailoring business.

2.  T. Thị B. Liên is a 52-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business of running a food stall.

3.  Đỗ Thị Luận is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business of raising livestock.

4.  N. Thị K. Yến is a 36-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her tailoring business.

5.  N. Thị Dung is a 40-year-old woman who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business of running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand a food sales business

loans.name: Reebok  F Group

texts.en:
Moshi M., 37, is married with two children, ages 17 and 10 years. She has run a cosmetics shop since 1996.  She works from 8am to 12pm daily and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $.229. 

This will be Moshi’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to expand her business and has paid the loans back successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to increase her stock even more and start selling new clothes.

Moshi will share this loan with subgroup F of the Reebok group. The subgroup has six members who own shops selling chips, cold drinks, fruits and vegetables.  These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Moshi is the only lady.

loans.use: To increase cosmetics stock and start clothing sales

loans.name: Silvia Lorena

texts.es: Silvia Lorena R. L. de 41 años de edad, reside en Ciudad Delgado ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador, vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos. Silvia posee su negocio hace cuatro años llamado ‘‘Tienda Lorena’’ donde vende variedad de productos de consumo, el deseo de Silvia es ampliar la gama de productos que tiene en su tienda por eso ella solicita un crédito que le ayude a surtir su negocio el cual ha ido creciendo en estos años y Silvia puesto mucha fe y esfuerzo en el, ella utilizara este crédito para surtir su negocio con el cual lograra obtener mayores ganancias para seguir consolidado su tienda.
texts.en:
Silvia Lorena is 41 years old, lives in Ciudad Delgado in the state of San Salvador. She lives there with her husband and two children. Silvia has had her business for four years called "Tienda Lorena" where she sells a variety of food products. Silvia's wish is to increase the variety of products she sells and for that she is asking for a loan that will help her replenish her stock. Her business has been growing in the last few years and Silvia has put a lot of faith and effort in it. She will use the money to replenish her stock and that in turn will generate more income to continue consolidating the her store.

Translated from Spanish by Linda Zamora, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replenish store stock

loans.name: Achol

texts.en:
Achol M. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to build a bar.  Achol is 29 years old and is married with a husband who works as a teacher. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open up a bar

loans.name: Nhok

texts.en: Nhok V. is a 48-year-old farmer who lives in Siem Reap Province. Nhok V. is married with three teenage children who are not very long in school and who work on the farm, while her husband also works with her in the farming business. Additionally, this couple has built a medium sized pen behind their house in which they raise many pigs for revenue. Because the farming business is the main way for the family to generate a profit, Nhok V. is pursuing a loan to grow rice and to buy more piglets to raise. This loan will provide her with additional income and comfortable living conditions.

loans.use: To grow rice and to buy more piglets to raise

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida I. is a resident of Barangay Madiangat in Quezon Nueva Vizcaya. She manages a hog raising business situated in her backyard. She is married to Romeo and they have been blessed with five children, two boys and three girls. Three of the children are already college graduates and two are still studying.  

Their major source of income is through farming, while hog raising is their family’s alternative source of income. Thus, Loida is asking the amount of PHP 5,000 that she can use as additional capital to support the feed supply of her hogs. Loida wishes the best for her family and she knows that through the support of lenders, she can achieve  her goals. She is also planning to venture into a vegetable vending business for additional income.

loans.use: To support the feed supply for her hogs

loans.name: María Gladis

texts.es: María Gladis M. R. reside en Apopa municipio de San Salvador. María  vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos solo tres aun menores de edad y estudiantes, y su hija mayor empleada, El esposo de María trabaja como motorista y gana $250.00 mensuales los cuales destina para los gastos de la casa; y María trabaja en su negocio una venta de tortillas en su casa. María y su esposo valoran lo importante que es apoyar a sus hijos para seguir estudiando ya que reconocen como les ha costado a ellos encontrar trabajos donde puedan  obtener ingresos dignos para sobrevivir, es por eso que María no se resigna a abandonar lo que sabe hacer y desea seguir creciendo en su negocio, mientras sus hijos sean unos profesionales, María solicita un crédito para compra de maíz ya que el precio de los granos ha subido en el mercado así que tendrá que aumentar sus comprar para poder ampliar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
María Gladis M. R. lives in the Apopa municipality of San Salvador. María lives with her husband and their four children. Three of her children are dependents who go to school. Her eldest daughter works. María’s husband works as a driver, and he earns $250 a month. This money is for the household expenses. María works in her business of selling tortillas in her house. María and her husband value how important it is to support their children so that they can continue their education. They recognize how difficult it was for them to find work where they could earn a decent living to survive. That is why María is not resigned to leaving what she knows how to do. She wants to keep growing in her business so that her children can become professionals. María is asking for a loan to buy corn because grain prices in the market have gone up. She will need to increase what she buys in order to increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn for tortillas

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina A. is currently in the business of selling rice and beans and is requesting a loan to purchase maize flour to sell. Sabina is 49 years old and married with a husband who works as a security guard. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel and buy a motor bike.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase maize flour to sell

loans.name: Puma Group

texts.en:
Shaban J., age 34, is married with two children, ages 5 and 1 year. He has a chicken business, which he started in 2007.  He works from 6am to 9pm daily and is able to earn a monthly profit of about $.65. 

This will be Shaban’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to increase the stock of his business and has paid the loans back successfully. He now hopes for a new loan to increase his stock even more by buying more chicks.

Shaban will share this loan with subgroup A of the Puma group. The subgroup has six members who own shops and a salon, and sell clothes, sarong and dry food. These members hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Shaban is the only man.

loans.use: To increase stock of chickens, and start clothing sales

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en:
Gideon M. is a 27-year-old man and a married father of two. He lives in Shanzu, Mombasa, where he runs a clothing stall. He has been in the business of selling clothes for eight years and he also owns a passenger service motorbike, which supplements his household income.

Gideon was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a KADET member. This will be his first loan. With the money, he plans to increase the clothing and bedding stock for his business and to also service his motorbike.

In the future he hopes to expand his business into a large clothing store and to also venture more into the transport industry by acquiring more motorbikes.

loans.use: To purchase stock of clothing and bedding for resale

loans.name: Aïtchatou

texts.fr: Aïtchatou est née vers 1950 à Pobè dans le Département de l'Ouémé, au Sud du Bénin.  Aïtchatou n’est jamais allée à l’école. Dès son jeune âge, Aïtchatou aida sa mère dans la vente des produits vivriers. Après son mariage, Aïtchatou s'est mise à son propre compte, mais pour vendre des divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.).  Aïtchatou vit à Cotonou,  Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin et est à son cinquième crédit avec ALIDé. Aïtchatou sollicite ce crédit-ci pour augmenter le volume de son activité qui connait depuis quelque temps un problème de stagnation.
texts.en:
Aïtchatou was born around 1950 in Pobè in Ouémé county, in southern Benin. She never went to school. From a young age, she helped her mother with selling staple goods. After her marriage, Aïtchatou started off on her own, though with selling sundry items: candies, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardine, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, batteries, candles, etc. She lives in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin and is on her fifth loan with ALIDé. She is requesting this loan to increase the volume of her business, which has been experiencing a problem with stagnation for quite awhile.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy canned milk, sardines, and tomatoes;  sugar, soaps, and school supplies

loans.name: Mak

texts.en: Raising pigs is the main portion of Mak L.’s daily routine. She also raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. She raises at least five pigs at a time and will sell them to buyers when the pigs are mature. Her husband assists her when he has free time from his work in construction. The couple married years ago and is blessed with two teenage children who are construction workers. Mak L. will be using the Kiva loan to buy a cow and extra pigs to raise in order to produce their babies for sale.

loans.use: To buy a cow and extra pigs to raise

loans.name: Joanna

texts.en:
Joanna M. is from the city of Oroquieta. She is 21 years old. Joanna is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Joanna's main source of income comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Joanna has been in  business for more than a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Joanna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joanna has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Joanna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Joanna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and supplies

loans.name: Annaliza

texts.en:
Annaliza M. is 42 years old and married to Renato, who is 47 years old and her business partner. She is a native of the island vilage in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. The island is sorrounded by lake and there are mountains on the island.

In 2004, Annaliza joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with hope to rise above poverty. Her previous loans were carefully spent on her business making kaing (large basket made from bamboo) as her primary business. The business runs smoothly and returns good proceeds for her family. A portion of her loans also went to her secondary business of reselling charcoal.

Now on her fifth loan, she is requesting a loan of 23,000 pesos as additonal capital for her kaing making business and also for her secondary business. The loan wil be used to pay for 100 pieces of bamboo, 10 rolls of binder, and for transportation expanses. Also, a portion of the loan will go to her secondary business, the resale of charcoal, as addtional capital.

She is hopeful that she can earn more income to save for her and her husband's future since they have no children. She still has hopes of having a child.

loans.use: To pay for supplies to make baskets from bamboo, plus transportation costs

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios (Remy) lives in the village of Madiangat in Quezon Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Ruben and they have been blessed with two children: Verfred - 5 years old and Merliza - 2 years old. Remy and her husband are looking forward to a bright future for their children.  

To further help her husband earn a living for their family, Remy started a snack vending business. She sells cooked snacks like soup, “pancit” (noodles) and sometimes she also sells vegetables. Aside from farming, her husband also works as a part-time house carpenter in their village. She used to earn PHP 500 per week from her simple vending business. She hopes that she will be able to borrow a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional capital.  She hopes that her income will continue to increase by having additional capital. She is doing her best to save money for the future of their children. She also does manicures and pedicures when her products are already sold. She is hoping that her business will become successful and that their children will finish their education someday. Through her hard work and patience, she believes that nothing is impossible.

loans.use: To raise additional capital for her snack vending business

loans.name: Rhodora

texts.en: Rhodora A. is from the town of Panaon. She is 34 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Rhodora owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Rhodora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Rhodora is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 16th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more beer and soft drinks in bulk

loans.name: 022-Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Liên N. Thị operates a family member's business providing general services to local community members. She is a 33-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Liên is married and has two school-age children. Liên has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,800,000 VND a month.

In 2005, Liên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities.  Liên has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her seventh loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Liên plans to use the additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children.

Liên (19) is the leader of a four member group accessing a loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 022 -Quảng Hưng (18.05.022).

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:
1.  N. Thị Huyền  is a 31-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector (50).
2.  H. Thị Tân is a 24-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food (37).
3.  Lê Thị Hoa is a 26-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business making and selling food (17).

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Liên N. Thị (19) là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Liên là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 022 -Quảng Hưng (18.05.022).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ nói chung cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Liên thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Liên kiếm được khoảng 1800000 VND.  Vào 2005, Liên đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Liên đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua vật tư cần thiết để cung cấp dịch vụ.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 7th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1.  N. Thị Huyền (50) là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

2.  H. Thị Tân (37) là 24 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

3.  Lê Thị Hoa (17) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."	

If you would like to translate the Vietnamese text above, please visit the free online translator offered by Vdict.com.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mariam O.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is Mariam M. from Mbozi. She is 37, married and has 6 children between the ages of 8 and 17. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependents because they are orphans. 
Mariam has been running a milk business since 1993; she purchases, prepares and sells milk.
She works at the business for 9-12 hours a day, 6 days a week,  and she is assisted by one employee. Mariam currently earns about 80 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to improve the quality of her business. In the future, she plans to open the same business at a new location. Mariam thanks you for your support!
ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To improve the quality of her business

loans.name: Z. Madeleine

texts.fr: Z. Madeleine est née en 1961 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Madeleine est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Madeleine n’a jamais été à l’école. Mais a été initiée dès son jeune âge au commerce par sa mère. Après son mariage, s’est mise à son propre compte pour vendre différents produits en gros, à savoir : crevettes, pétrole lampant, tissus et bijoux. Madeleine livre à crédit les crevettes et le pétrole lampant aux détaillants. C’est à crédit que Madeleine livre également les tissus et bijoux, mais aux particuliers. Madeleine est à son quatrième crédit avec ALIDé. Madeleine sollicite ce crédit pour renforcer son fonds de commerce afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle
texts.en:
Z. Madeleine was born in 1961 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. She is married and the mother of three. Madeleine has never been to school. But when she was young, she was introduced to commerce by her mother. After Madeleine was married, she started off on her own selling different goods wholesale, namely: shrimp, lamp fuel, cloth, and jewelry. She delivers shrimp and lamp fuel on credit to retailers. On credit is also how she delivers cloth and jewelry, though to private individuals. Madeleine is on her fourth loan with ALIDé and is requesting it in order to boost her working capital, so as to respond better to the demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy baskets of shrimp, cloth, and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo lives in Barangay Arellano of Tuguegarao City.  He is married to Dace Jane and they have two children.  They want to give their children a better future by providing them with college educations. 

Romeo owns and manages a computer shop in the city.  With his desire to develop his business, he also offers snacks and electronic cellphone loaders inside his shop.  He requests a loan of PHP30, 000 that he will use as additional business capital. He also plans to use the loan to purchase at least five more computers.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok R. owns and operates a medium size pigpen, where she raises at least six pigs. Another source of family income comes from her husband, who owns and operates a battery-charging service for neighbors. This determined couple has one young child. Sok R. will use half of her loan to purchase pig food and piglets for breeding and the rest to buy rice in bulk at reasonable prices from farmers, then resell to customers at higher prices, thus gaining income.

loans.use: To purchase pig food and piglets for breeding

loans.name: Jeralyn

texts.en:
Jeralyn operates a humble community-based store.  She is a widow and lives in the village of Cebu San Isidro, Isabela.  Her store has been of great help in providing the needs of her family.  She has two children: Edralyn, 25 and Maricel, 23. Neither of her children could finish their college education because of financial problems. 

Jeralyn wants to improve her business, so she asks for help from Kiva lenders for a loan of  PHP5, 000. She wants her family to overcome the hardships of life, so she is doing her best in managing her store.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Aziza R.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is Aziza S. from Mbozi. She is 31, married and has one 6 year old child. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphan.
Aziza has been selling used clothing and drinks since 2007. Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Tanzania to retailers such as Aziza, who re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets and in the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because of their low cost and the general appeal of anything modern. 
She works 13 - 16 hours a day, 6 days a week and is assisted by one employee and by her husband. Aziza currently earns about 210USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more clothes and drinks in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and the range of her business. Aziza thanks you for your support!
ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and drinks in bulk

loans.name: H. Eliane

texts.fr: Eliane est née le 02 Janvier 1972 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Eliane est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Eliane n’a jamais été à l’école. Eliane a été placée auprès d’un parent dès son jeune âge. Eliane a aidé cette parente à vendre la nourriture et autres articles de grande consommation. Après son mariage, Eliane s’est mise à son propre compte pour vendre les divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.). Eliane est à son cinquième crédit avec ALIDé. Eliane sollicite ce prêt-ci pour renforcer son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Eliane was born on January 2, 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. She is married and the mother of three. Eliane has never attended school. Eliane was placed with one parent at a young age. She helped this parent to sell food and other heavily-consumed goods. After she was married, Eliane started off on her own selling sundry items: candies, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardines, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, batteries, candles, etc. She is on her fifth loan with ALIDé and is requesting it in order to bolster her business and to respond better to the demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy:  canned tomatoes, liqueurs, drums of vegetable oil, pasta, canned milk, and soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk for her business.

loans.name: 25 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Oanh N. Thị N. (172) is  62 and lives in the town of Thanh Hóa.  Oanh is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 25 Nam Ngạn (17.09.25).


Oanh is married and has 3 adult-aged children.  Oanh owns & operates a food stall where she sells assorted foods & snacks to the local community.  Oanh has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1.500.000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2008, Oanh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Oanh repaid a previous loan of 1.963.500 VND, which she used to invest in expanding the business.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which she will use for the same reason. This will be her 3rd loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Oanh plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. Thị Huệ (173) is 38 and is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her food stall business.


2.  Lê Thị Liên (175) is  54 and is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her food stall business.


3.  N. Thị Huệ (176) is 45 and is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store.


4.  T. Thị Lý (177) is 43 and is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her food stall business.


5.  N. Thị Lan (174) is  49 and is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her food stall business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Oanh N. Thị N. (172) là 62 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hóa.  Oanh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 25 Nam Ngạn (17.09.25).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán hàng tạp hóa trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Oanh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Oanh kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND.  Vào 2008, Oanh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Oanh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.963.500 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Huệ (173) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


2.  Lê Thị Liên (175) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


3.  N. Thị Huệ (176) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


4.  T. Thị Lý (177) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


5.  N. Thị Lan (174) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .
