loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase mobile phone accessories in bulk for her business

loans.name: Indira

texts.en:
Indira Burić is a 41-year-old women who comes from the town of Banovići. She is married and has two sons. Her husband is employed in a local company.

Indira has a stand at the local market where she sells shoes. She did that part time when she was employed in a factory as a tailor. Then she decided to extend that business at the market and do just that. Besides that, she does embroidery as a hobby and for orders.

Indira requested her first loan from WWI (Žene za Žene International) for 1,500 KM to invest in her shoe business and in her embroidery hobby.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell and materials for her embroidery hobby

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase clothes in bulk for her business

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen A. is the picture of a woman who is very determined to cut the ties of poverty that hinder her way to success. She believes that business is a starting step to achieve something higher, provided it is properly managed. Now on her third loan, she is requesting 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her fishing business. Specifically, the loan will pay for two bundles of fishnets, 60 pieces of bamboo, and for the repair of her fish cage.

Carmen is a native of the island town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is married to Apolinario, who is a 57-year-old fisherman. She is the mother of two daughters: her elder daughter, Helen, is 35 years old and her younger daughter, Mary Ann, is 18 years old.

In 2007, she joined Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, with high hopes and aspirations to have access to capital for her business. Her previous loans were used as rolling capital for her fishing business and also, partly, as capital for her secondary sewing business. She is hopeful that with hard work and proper use of capital, she can make her business grow. She dreams of having more fish cages and her own sewing machine. She also wants to be able to improve her house into one more spacious and durable.

loans.use: To pay for fishnets, bamboo and the repair of a fish cage

loans.name: 001-Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Huệ Lê Thị's main source of income comes from operating a family member's business raising pigs for sale. She is a 60-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Huệ is married and has three adult children. Huệ has been in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month.

In 2005, Huệ joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Huệ has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock to raise and sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase more livestock to raise and sell. This will be her eighth loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Huệ plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income. (32)

Huệ is the leader of a six member group accessing a loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 001-Quảng Hưng (18.04.001).

About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.use: To purchase more commodities and clothes in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Armelle

texts.fr: Armelle née le 16 Aout 1972 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Armelle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Armelle a été à l’école. Après l'abandon des classes, Armelle s'est mise dans de petits commerces. Aujourd’hui, avec l'aide financière de son mari, Armelle a pu démarrer une vraie activité d'alimentation générale. Armelle a besoin de renforcer son fonds de commerce pour mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Armelle sollicite d’ALIDé son troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Armelle was born on August 16, 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin.  She is married and the mother of three.  Armelle has been in school.  After dropping out, she started off in small-scale businesses.  Today, with financial help from husband, she was able to start a real business in grocery items.  Armelle needs to bolster her working capital in order to respond better to the demands of her customers.  For this reason, she is requesting her third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of rice, corn, onions, canned food, drums of vegetable oil, etc.

loans.name: Salome A.

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 29-year-old Salome M. from Mbozi. She is married with two children, ages 4 and 6. Salome has been running a retail shop business since 2007. She owns a small "duka" or neighborhood shop in the city, where she sells common household and grocery items.

She works at the business for nine to 12 hours per day, six days per week. Salome currently earns about $250 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase shop items in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to improve the quality and range of products in her "duka." Salome thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk for her business

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 55-year-old married woman with four children between 10 and 27 years old.  Three of her children are in school. The eldest child is working. She resides in and owns a one-room house where she is staying with six people. Margaret doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  There is electricity and piped water at her home.  The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area where she owns a stall selling bananas in Kalerwe market.  She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work.  Margaret sells to an average of 25 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and feeding the family.  She has been in this business for the last 10 years. Margaret has been with MCDT for eight years and is servicing her 16th loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more clusters of bananas. Margaret aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent home. 
 

.

loans.use: To buy more banana clusters

loans.name: Mygrate G.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 22-year-old Mygrate M. from Mbozi. She is married with two children between the ages of one and four. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant because he is an orphan. Mygrate has been running a rice-selling business since 2007. She buys rice from farmers at wholesale and sells in town at retail. She works at the business for 9 – 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Mygrate currently earns about 150USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of rice in bulk to resell. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of her business. Mygrate thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice in bulk

loans.name: Nazokat

texts.en:
B. Nazokat is 37 years old. She is married and has two children. Nazokat has been running a grocery store for the past 12 years. She sells sweets, sugar, preserved food, juices, soft drinks and also different kinds of toys for children. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Nazokat is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her vending facility to buy groceries again. Nazokat is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 4700 Somoni to increase the inventory she has for sale. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Nazokat reach all of her aspirations.         


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Shoira

texts.en:
Shoira is a married mother of two children. She has three years experience in her tailor shop. On her own initiative, she began to elaborate garments, which she then began to sell. This endeavor went very well and little by little, she has been purchasing different kinds of sewing machines for her store. She works every day of the week from 8am to 5pm. Shoira is requesting this loan in order to purchase a new electrical sewing machine, which is currently on sale, and she needs it very much. With this investment, she will be able to improve her earnings and to improve her store. And so she will be able to give a better survive to her customers. Shoira would like to be able, little by little, to improve her quality of life and to remodel her tailor shop so that it looks nicer.

loans.name: Akbarshoh

texts.en:
The need to improve his income and provide education to his four dear children is the reason Akbarshoh is courteously requesting this loan. He is a very responsible and hardworking father who for many years was dedicated to the business of buying and selling shoes. With the income, he said he was able to educate his children as it is most important for Akbarshoh. Today he is requesting a loan of $800 USD to expand the business so that he can generate more income for the well-being of his family. Akbarshoh is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to achieve his dreams with this loan. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. loans.use: To purchase new shoes to sell

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
M. MADINA
ID:11967700001702056
KIGALI BRANCH(VFC FIELD OFFICE)
CREDIT OFFICER: NYIRAMARIRO SPECIOSE

Greetings from Kigali,

M. Madina is 42 years old, married to one husband, and has six children (24, 23, 19, 15, 12, and 9 years old).She is experienced for six years in selling clothes for children and dishes at Kigali-Nyarugenge with a profit of 200,000RWF each month. Now she is applying for her first loan from Vision Finance Company in Rwanda for 500,000 Rwandan Francs. With this loan, she hopes to expand her business by buying more clothes for children and dishes for selling in order to get more profits than before. At this time, she is selling as a retailer because of poor investment but she hopes that once she gets the loan, it will permit her to sell as a retailer and wholesaler at the same time. By doing both operations, obviously she will get more profits than before. And with the increased profits, she expects to send her children to beautiful schools for higher education and get more food for her family.

loans.use: To buy clothes for children and dishes

loans.name: Abduhalim

texts.en:
K. Abduhalim is 42 years old. He is married and has four children. He is a hard-working man struggling to feed his children and parents (who are living with him) by selling national fabrics for the national dresses. Abduhalim has a trading place in the center local markets of Dushanbe city. He is trying to have wide range of goods to meet the requirements of his customers and to satisfy the needs of the clients with different levels of income. Abduhalim, being a devoted father, is doing all the best in order for his children to be well educated and happy. Today Abduhalim feels that with more working capital his business could generate more income, so he is asking for a loan of 8500 Somoni to jumpstart the business and raise the family's standard of living. Let's help this incredible father give his children a brighter future.

loans.use: To purchase new fabrics for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: Istatoy

texts.en: N. Istatoy is 33 years old. She is married and is the mother of two children. Istatoy's lack of a stable job and the slow productivity of her husband's business as an ecologist didn't leave enough money to pay the expenses of the family. This was the reason that Istatoy decided to start her own business eight years ago, selling national dresses for women. Little by little she has made her business grow and, by offering her clients installment payments, her orders are getting bigger. Now Istatoy’s business is running normally. However, she would like to continue bettering herself and her business so that her situation will be stable in the future. She is asking for a loan of 3,000 Somoni that will enable her to buy new garments for her business. The power to help her business grow is in your hands. loans.use: To purchase more national dresses to sell

loans.name: Zarifa

texts.en:
For more than 15 years, Zarifa has been a business owner by selling different kinds of foodstuff and school items. Her business is situated near a local school where there are always a lot of schoolchildren, so the business is very stable and generates a stable income for her family.

Mavzuna has been working with IMON for 4 years and has proven herself to be an accurate client. Today she requests 5,000 Somoni for purchasing school items due to the coming of the 1st of September. Mavzuna thanks all for support and promises to pay the loan in time. loans.use: Purchasing school items for selling.

loans.name: Shamsiya

texts.en:
K. Shamsiya is 42 years old. Shamsiya and her husband have been married for almost 20 years and have raised two wonderful children. Shamsiya has been running her own small business for 8 years already. She has a place for selling items such as soft drinks, sweets, potted goods, detergents, soap, toothpaste and others.

She works from 7:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. Shamsiya is very friendly and polite which allows her to have the clientele. Now she is requesting 3,550 Somoni that she will spend to purchase more goods for selling, thus increasing her range of products. She thanks everyone who have decided to support her. loans.use: Increasing of stock, purchasing goods for selling

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
K. Mahbuba is a 40 year-old married mother of 4 children. She has been selling clothing for kids and men’s shoes at the local market for the past 15 years. Because of this, she will be able to pay for her children to finish school. With low capital, she is not able to buy larger quantities of clothing to sell.

Mahbuba would like to use the loan to buy more bales of clothing that contain more variety to increase her stock. She hopes to raise enough income to support all of her children to finish school. Be an important part of the well being of this humble family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. loans.use: Increasing of working capital with the purpose of business development.

loans.name: Mildred Atieno

texts.en:
Mildred O. is 43 years old and married with four children. Her husband works as a technician. She lives in the very high populated area of Kangemi where she has set up her business and her customers range from retailers to one-time stop customers.

Mildred was introduced to KADET by her business friends who are already registered as KADET clients. She has not borrowed from other sources and this is her third loan with KADET. So far she has successfully paid all the other loans well and on time.

For her to keep up with the demand, she needs to equip her tailoring shop with a good embroidery machine so as to meet her clients' desires. Mildred also intends to keep a good stock of assorted fabrics so that her clients have a wide variety to choose from. From her own experience she says this will give her an upper hand in the competitive market.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of fabric and a new sewing machine for her embroidery work

loans.name: Gulbara's Group

texts.en: Gulbara is the leader of this group. Her family members include a husband and three children. Her husband is an electrician working at the electric power station of Kant city. The eldest among her children is her daughter, who is a sophomore. Next is her son, an eleven-year-old youngster. The smallest is her next son, who is just two years old. It is pretty hard to have three children and be an electrician. Nevertheless, Gulbara tries to help her husband as best as she can by selling milk. All these years she has been quite successful as she sells ten liters a day at twenty cents per liter, which is a significant source of income. Besides that, she sells eggs, a little over a dollar per ten eggs. Gulbara needs to buy a two-chamber fridge for $440. However, considering the amount of money she and her husband earn, it is unlikely that they would ever be able to save money to do that. So, they hope that they will be able to get a loan. Gulbara’s partners are Suyunbek, Aigul, Sabyrkul and Uruila. Suyunbek is married and he has two children. While his wife looks after their children, he is occupied with raising livestock. He has been engaged in this business for thirteen years. He wants to obtain a loan and buy three sheep. Aigul, 43, is the mother of seven children! Her husband sells motor oils in Bishkek city while Aigul is engaged in cattle breeding and selling milk. This activity has helped her support her family and marry her two daughters. Sabyrkul, 53, is married and has four children. Both she and her spouse are farmers, growing and utilizing agricultural products. They obtained their land fifteen years ago from the local municipality. Sabyrkul needs a loan to purchase 150 bales of hay. Uruila, 54, is married. Two years ago she saved some money and bought a milk cow. Now, selling milk brings her $55. She hopes to buy another cow to sell more milk. However, only through obtaining a loan would she be able to do that. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a two-chamber fridge to store her produce

loans.name: Noroy

texts.en: R. Noroy has been selling a big variety of foodstuffs in her grocery store for the past twenty years. She is married and has six children. A true entrepreneur, she studies the market to determine client needs and preferences. Industrious and enterprising, Noroy is focused on expanding her business. Noroy is currently seeking a loan of 11,000 Somoni. She plans to use the loan to increase her assortment of fresh merchandise and to expand her business. With the increased sales and profits, Noroy hopes to expand her grocery and improve the living standard of her family. loans.use: To increase her assortment of fresh merchandise and to expand her business

loans.name: Sainaya's Group

texts.en: The leader of the group, Sainaya, is sixty. Almost all of the five children brought up by her are now grown-ups. Her two daughters and two sons live separately as they have their own families. Only her little son stays with his parents as he is still a college student. To make a living, her husband farms land and raises livestock. As to Sainaya, she keeps two cows and sells their milk to the locals. Actually, one of her cows was given to her by her father and mother-in-law as a wedding gift. Now this gift lets her make $45 a month. Raising cattle has allowed them to marry two of their sons and even increase the total population. Sainaya has far-going plans. The first obstacle is getting a loan. Once it is overcome, she plans to buy two calves which she is going to fatten up for resale. As she sells them, she intends to invest the money in buying a flat for her daughter in Tokmok city. After fulfilling this plan she will be able to finish building her house, which is now under construction. Here is Sainaya’s team – Rosa, Chynarkan and Kulbubu: Rosa is a widow and is the mother of five children. She manages to keep a cow, a horse and five sheep. She is happy to have married her three daughters, despite her low income. Rosa wants to buy a cow. However, without a loan she won’t be able to do that. Chynarkan, 47, is the mother of five children, most of whom go to college. This is quite burdensome since neither she nor her husband have a good income. They mainly live by keeping cattle. Chynarkan needs a loan to buy a foal which, after feeding for one year, they plan to resell. Kulbubu, 48, is a widow. She has brought up six children, some of whom help her now. She keeps two cows and sells milk which helps her make $20 a month, enough to sustain her for a month. She hopes to get a loan and buy a calf. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy two calves for fattening and resale

loans.name: Batima's Group

texts.en:
Here is Batima, the leader of this loan group. She is 47 years old and a widow with four children. To make a living she has to raise cattle. Because it is a very difficult activity for a woman, she gets help from her relatives. At the beginning, she did not have any idea how to keep and look after cattle. However, being a smart woman and having caring relatives, she quickly learned the necessary aspects and developed good skills. Now she has three sheep and wants to increase their number. 

Her plan is to achieve the desired population step by step. First, she hopes to obtain a loan and buy one calf. After feeding and resale, she is going to buy two calves for fattening and resale again and so on. Constant concern about her children’s future and awareness that there is nobody except her to take care of them, strengthens her determination and makes her steadfast. One of her future plans is to build a new house for her children. 

Batima has three partners, Aina, Chynarkul and Zeinep. Aina, age 43, is married. Her husband works as a farmer. They keep twenty sheep at home and Aina has to look after them in addition to doing her duties. Aina wants to buy ten more sheep and thus increase their population. She hopes to do that by obtaining a loan.

Chynarkul, 52, is a widow. All three of her children are adults. To keep herself busy, she decided to undertake cattle breeding. Currently she has three calves and hopes to get a loan to buy two more. 

Zeinep is the youngest partner. She is just twenty-one years old. She is married and has six-month old daughter. Being a housewife, Zeinep’s needs a refridgerator, becaue it is summer and everything spoils very quickly. She hopes that, after getting a loan, she will finally be able to buy a new refridgerator.    

======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). loans.use: To buy a calf for resale

loans.name: Abdusalim

texts.en:
S. Abdusalim is 31 years old. He married and has three children. His wife is a housekeeper and she supports him in everything he does. Abdusalim is a hard-working person and he has been providing taxi services for the past 7 years. The most important thing to him is that his children successfully finish school and graduate from the university, so that they will have a better future as professionals. 

Abdusalim wishes to buy new car, and for this he needs to have his working tools in good working order. He believes that the new car that he is planning to buy will allow him to earn more and to improve his family living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a new car for his taxi service

loans.name: Adylneverra Akoth

texts.en:
Adylneverra O. is 30 years old. She is married and has one child. Her husband works as a mechanic. 

Adylneverra sells her goods by hawking (selling door-to-door). She displays traditional bags at a high class shopping mall. Due to the nature of her business, she meets many people and this is an added advantage, because she makes new business contacts each time.

She was introduced to KADET by the chairlady of her group. This will be her first loan from a financial institution. She want to use the loan to add more stock for her business.

Adylneverra hopes eventually to set up her own high quality tailoring business. She wants to make designer clothes and bags for her customers.

loans.use: Adylneverra wants to add more stock of both clothes and traditional bags.

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en:
Greetings from Kigali-Rwanda!

B. claudine is 34 years old and married to one husband.  She has 3 children (13 years, 10 years, 8 years).  She has 2 years of experience in selling clothes of kids and the monthly profit from her business is 100,000.  Now she is requesting her first loan, of 500,000, from Vision Finance Company.   This loan will be used to increase her business by buying for selling more kids clothes so that she may gain more than before.  Once she gains more, she will be better able to to develop herself and to support her family.  She will support her family by supplying food and sending her children in good schools for better education.  Beyond that, she will even be able to help others.

loans.use: clothes of kids

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en: L. Annet is a devoted and hard-working lady who sells fish as her business. She is a married lady with 6 children aged 20 – 12 years. One of her children is in the university and the rest in secondary schools. She also cares for orphaned children. She operates from Lugazi's central market and, although she started on a small scale, she is now a wholesaler and is able to earn 150,000/= in profits each week. This is Annet’s 12th loan and she plans to buy more fish for her business so that she can make more profits. This will enable her to pay her children’s school fees and general upkeep, thereby improving her standard of living.

loans.use: Buying more fish for resale.

loans.name: Selina's Group

texts.en:
Selina N. is a hard-working and friendly lady. She has been selling fish in the Lugazi central market for 22 years. She buys her fish from the landing sites in Lugazi and Mukono and, because she has been in the business for a long time, she knows where to buy which fish and from whom. 

However, Selina says that before she sold fish, she was a farmer, and because money is hard to come by for a farmer, unless one is on a large scale, she resorted to fish selling, and has no regrets about the change. She hopes to expand her business so that she can supply fish to her fellow workers so that she can be able to sell much more. 

Selina is a widow with 6 children of her own and 4 step-children that she cares for. This requires her to work so hard. 

(Benita appeared in both subgroups of the Nakazadde group and is being considered to be a member of this one.)

loans.use: Buying more fish for resale in her business.

loans.name: Yeko's Group

texts.en:
N. Yeko is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a hard-working business lady who has been selling agricultural products, such as matooke and sweet potatoes, for 10 years. Yeko started on a very small scale in the Lugazi Central market but, at the moment, she is able to make profits worth 150,000/= a week. She says that her loans enable her to stock quality produce and enable her business to move swiftly. 

She plans to builda a residential house for her family and ensure that all her children get a quality education. Yeko needs a loan to help increase the capital in her business so that she is able to buy more produce to resell. This is Yeko’s 35th loan and she and her businesses have grown because of them. She is 50 years and married with 6 children ages 16 to 35, because she also takes care of orphans.

loans.use: Buying more produce for resale.

loans.name: Grace's Group

texts.en:
Grace M. is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 40 years old and married with 6 children, ages 5 to 24, all of whom attend school. 

Grace has a poultry farm business where she keeps chickens both for meat and eggs. Her markets are in Nkokonjeru and Lugazi. She has spent 8 years in the same business and, as a result, she has been able to own an organized home. She also has cows that she milks to pay fees for her children. She is grateful that the loans have managed to improve her business and the sky is the limit for her future developments. 

She has ordered more day-old chicks, both layers and broilers, and her loan will help her to complete payment and buy feed for her poultry farm.

loans.use: Buying more chicks and chicken feed to expand her farm.

loans.name: Kasokoso Central 1 West Nadego Regina Group

texts.en: Regina N. is a hard-working business woman who has stayed in her business for over twenty years. She is a tailor who makes traditional clothing such as gomes and bitegi. She is using the loan to purchase material and other supplies for making clothes. She is forty-three years old and married, and she has six children, all of whom are in school. She is an experienced tailor who is trying to capture the market from most of the corners by making what is best for customers. Her future plan is to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase material and other supplies for making clothes.

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Mrs. Ma. Fe B. is 49 years old, married and blessed with 2 children. She and her family live in Barangay Lamak Rizal, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. Ma. Fe ekes out a living for her family by selling fruits and vegetables. She admits that this is not an easy way to earn a living because it requires patience and a lot of hard work and dedication, but she is firm in her goal to help her husband move their family out of poverty. 

She has been an traveling fruit vendor for that last 10 years, going around the villages and neighboring towns selling different kinds of fruit, such as mangos, bananas, or whatever fruit is in season just to help her husband support their family and meet their basic needs. 

Ma. Fe is thankful for the help of the loans she got from NWTF-Project Dungganon. She used the loans as capital for her fruit vending business, which now earns about PHP 5,000 per month.

For her 16th loan, Ma. Fe is borrowing PHP 19,000 which she will again use as additional capital for her business so that she can pay the tuition fees of her children.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To buy fruit to sell to the community

loans.name: Erlinda Elizabeth

texts.es: Erlinda Elizabeth F. L. reside en el municipio de Apopa del departamento de San Salvador. Erlinda cuenta con 34 años de edad,se encuentra casada con Alfredo quien trabaja en la PNC y tiene una niña de cinco años de edad llamada Vanessa. Erlinda y su esposo se apoyan mutuamente en los gastos económicos ella se desempeña en su propio negocio una tienda de productos de consumo, siempre la acompaña su pequeña hija ya que no hay quien cuide de ella, y tampoco la han podido inscribir al kínder, Erlinda desea aumentar su inventario a través de este crédito solicitado, que  le ayuda a incrementar sus ventas al igual que  sus ganancias y dándole la oportunidad a Vanesa de poderla inscribir en el kínder; ya que requiere de muchos gastos por tantos materiales escolares y didácticos que le solicitan.
texts.en:
Erlinda Elizabeth resides in Apopa county in the state of San Salvador. Erlinda is 34 years old, married to Alfredo who works at the PNC, and has a 5 year-old daughter named Vanessa. Erlinda and her husband help each other with household's expenses. She works in her own business, a store with food products, always in the company of her small daughter since there is no one else to take care of her and who she hasn't been able to enroll in kindergarten. Erlinda wishes to increase her store's inventory with this loan which will help her increase her sales and her profits to give Vanessa the opportunity to be enrolled in kindergarten given the many expenses required for the many school and didactic materials they ask for.

Translated from Spanish by Linda Zamora, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replenish store stock

loans.name: Virgen De Copacabana Group

texts.es: El grupo ”Virgen de Copacabana” esta representada por el señor Richard Nelson quien junto a los 12 miembros del grupo van cursando juntos su tercer ciclo demostrando puntualidad, responsabilidad y unidad. Una mayoría de los miembros del grupo se dedica a la venta de ropa usada, venta de comida, carnes frías y actividades como la construcción y la confección de prendas de vestir, los socios se encuentran en constantes viajes para acomodar su mercadería ya que su mayor mercado se encuentran en provincias alejadas de la ciudad. El propósito de este nuevo financiamiento es para incrementar su materia prima como tela y material de construcción y mercadería como mas ropa para poder abarcar a todas las provincias lejanas y así poder tener mayores ingresos para darles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida. El nivel competitivo es alto en los mercados centrales es por esta razón que se ven forzados a sacar su mercadería a las diferentes provincias de la ciudad buscando mercados donde no haya tanta competencia. En relación a la experiencia crediticia se encuentran juntos desde el primer ciclo en la institución por lo que conocen claramente de crédito solidarios.
texts.en:
The group “Virgen de Copacabana” is represented by Señor Richard Nelson, who along with the twelve members of his group, are in their third loan cycle and always demonstrate punctuality, responsibility, and unity. A majority of the members of the group earn their living selling second-hand clothing, food, and cold cuts, or in activities such as construction and dressmaking. The members travel around constantly selling their merchandise as their biggest markets are found in areas a long way from the city. The purpose of this new loan is to obtain more items such as material, building supplies, and clothing so the members can sell in distant areas and earn more money to provide their families with a better quality of life. There is a lot of competition in the central markets so the members are forced to take their products to more distant areas, seeking markets where there is not so much competition. With regard to their experience with credit, the group has been together since the first loan cycle with the institution so they have a good understanding of the group loan system.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: operating capital

loans.name: Milagro Del Carmen

texts.es: Milagro Del Carmen L. D. M. D. 51 años D. edad vive en Apopa municipio D. la capital D. El Salvador. Milagro vive con su esposo quien trabaja en el molino aportando $100.00 US a la familia y sus cuatro hijos todos menores D. edad y estudiantes. Milagro es una madre responsable con su familia ella siempre está atenta a las necesidades, manifiesta que son sus hijos el motivo D. día a día para seguir trabajando  ya que les da a la oportunidad D. ser mejores personas académicamente cosa que Milagro y su esposo no lograron. Milagro posee una tienda D. productos D. consumo para el hogar y también una venta D. pupusas y tortillas, el destino del crédito que solicita Milagro es para invertir en sus negocios surtiendo su tienda y para compra D. materia prima para pupusas y tortillas que le ayuden a aumentar su producción.
texts.en:
51-year old Milagro Del Carmen L. D. M. lives in the municipality of Apopa in the capital of El Salvador. She lives with her husband who works in the mill and brings in US$100 for their family consisting of four children, all of whom are students and still dependent on them. Milagro is a responsible mother; she always attends to their needs, and says that her children are what motivates her on a daily basis to carry on working. She wants to give them the opportunity to get a good education, something that neither Milagro nor her husband has been able to achieve. Milagro owns a store selling products for the home, and as well she sells puposas (a typical dish from El Salvador like a tortilla) and tortillas. She wants to use the loan to buy more goods for her store and to buy ingredients for the pupusas and tortillas so that she can increase production.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for cooking and stock for her store

loans.name: Maricela Antonia

texts.es: Maricela Antonia R. Vda. D. C. D. 62 años D. edad resiD. en Atiquizaya en el departamento D. San Salvador. Tras la muerte D. su esposo, Marcela vive solamente con su hijo quien es comerciente ambulante. Maricela cuenta con una trayectoria D. veinte años D. experiencia en la comercialización D.  ropa, perfumes y cosméticos, sus ventas las hace D. manera ambulante, visitando a sus clientes casa por casa, pero quienes ya la conocen pueden ver sus productos en la casa D. Maricela; la razón por la cual hoy solicita este crédito es  porque desea aumentar su inventario y surtir su negocio D. más variedad D. productos.
texts.en:
62-year old Maricela Antonia R. Vda. D. C. lives in Atiquizaya in the department of San Salvador. Since her husband died, she has lived alone with her son who is a travelling salesman. Maricela has twenty years of experience selling clothing, perfume, and cosmetics. She goes from house to house visiting her customers, although those who know her can see the products in her home. She would like a loan so she can increase her inventory and stock her business with a greater variety of products.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: María Adela

texts.es: María Adela V. T. de 46 años de edad vive en el departamento de La Paz junto a su esposo y sus cuatro hijos todos estudiantes, María posee su negocio una venta de bebidas y golosinas ubicada en un complejo educativo, María tiene ya nueve años de tener a cargo este negocio con el cual ha logrado ayudar a su esposo económicamente y sacar a delante  a sus hijos, María ve ahora la oportunidad de solicitar este préstamo para surtir su negocio que carece de muchos productos los cuales vendería ya que no posee competencia algún en el complejo; es por eso que solicita este crédito para surtir su negocio y tener la oportunidad de ampliar sus metas de ventas.
texts.en:
María Adela V. T. is 46 years old and lives in the district of La Paz with her husband and their four children, who are students. For nine years, she has been operating a business at a school campus selling soft drinks and candy. The income generated from this business has allowed María to assist her husband with the finances and enabled her children to get ahead.

María has taken the opportunity to request a loan to restock her business with many of the products that are low in supply. There are no other competing businesses on campus, so this loan will give her the opportunity to expand her sales goals.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Restock her business

loans.name: Rosario Group

texts.es: El grupo “Rosario” esta bajo la presidencia de la señora Elizabeth y se encuentra conformada por 12 miembros que ya van cursando juntos su tercer siclo en los cuales han demostraron responsabilidad, honestidad unión y mucha solidaridad, son gente con ganas de trabajar y salir adelante. La mayoría de las socias se dedica al comercio de abarrotes, venta de carne de pollo, dulces y artefactos eléctricos el resto de los socios se dedica a la confección de prendas deportivas y a la elaboración de tejidos en telares artesanales. La competencia en el mercado de venta de productos es alta pero las socias saben como salir adelante alejándose del mercado central debido a la competencia, entre las socias que se dedican a la confesión de ropa y tejidos artesanales tienen clientela debido a la calidad de sus productos que se diferencian del resto gracias a sus diseños y calidad. El destino del financiamiento es para la adquisición de mercadería, insumos y materia prima para aumentar sus ventas y por ende sus ingresos que son el sustento de sus hogares.
texts.en:
The “Rosario” Group is led by Sra. Elizabeth, the president, and is comprised of 12 members who are working together on their third loan cycle. They have demonstrated responsibility, honesty, cooperation, and camaraderie. The members are eager to work in order to get ahead. The majority of them have retail businesses that sell groceries, chicken, candy, and electrical appliances. The remaining members manufacture sportswear and hand-woven articles.

Competition is quite high, so the members are aware that they must conduct their business away from the central market in order to succeed. The members who produce clothing and handicrafts have distinguished their products from other vendors because of their design and quality, and their customers have noticed.

The loans issued to the group will be used to acquire merchandise, supplies, and materials so that the members can increase their sales and earn more income to support their households.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Ama Brigitte

texts.fr:
Cette femme  exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des produits cosmétiques, elle fait ce commerce depuis 1998 et s'approvisionne au grand marché de lomé. Elle reçoit beaucoup de commande de ses clients. Son stock ayant connu une baisse, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter divers produits cosmétiques afin de rehausser son stock.
Elle est mariée  et mère de 02 enfants. C’est avec le revenu de son activité qu’elle contribue  aux charges de sa famille
texts.en:
This is a woman who earns an income from commerce in cosmetic products.  She has been in this business since 1998 and gets her supplies at the grand marketplace in Lomé.  She receives many orders from her customers.  Since her inventory experienced a drop, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy various cosmetics in order to replenish her stock.  She is married and the mother of two.  With the revenues from her business, she helps cover family expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetic products to sell

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane D. sells bread and tea at a restaurant. She is requesting a loan to purchase food to cook and sell in the retaurant. D. is 30 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 3 children who go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a generator to generate power to run her refrigerator and other necessities for her restaurant. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy food for her restaurant

loans.name: Yuri Jamileth

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua, la señora Yuri O. se dedica arduamente a su negocio de venta de cosméticos de todo tipo como lo son los de cremas, perfumes, shampoo, fragancias, gelatinas, entre otros.

Su necesidad es que requiere la compra de estos productos para ofertarlos en su negocio y para ello ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar el crédito oportuno y de esta manera continuar en su negocio siempre llevando el sustento a su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
At the wholesale market in the city of Managua, Sra. Yuri O. is hard at work selling all kinds of cosmetics such as creams, perfumes, shampoos, fragrances, gels, and other products.

She has come to CEPRODEL to request a loan to buy more products for her business. This will enable her business to continue and allow her to maintain her household.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en:
Annet M. is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a 43-year-old lady with two businesses. She sells spare parts for wood cutting equipment and she runs a poultry business. She has been raising layers and selling eggs on a large scale for 18 years. 

She says that the secret to her success is the good customer care, marketing skills and loans that add capital every 4 months, enabling her to care for her children and pay their school fees. 

Annet is able to make 300,000/= (300,000 Ugandan shillings) in profits every week and she would like this to increase even more. She needs a loan to help restock her retail spare shop with more equipment and to buy more feed for her chicks.

Annet is a married lady. She has 7 children, ages 13 - 22 years, including orphans that she cares for. All of her children are in school and she helps to pay for all of their school fees.

loans.use: Buying chicken feed and spare parts for business expansion.

loans.name: Kasokoso Central 2 West Namagada Zauda Group

texts.en: Zauda  N. is a young business lady. She is 20 years old and married and has one child. She has been selling charcoal for two years. She is requesting a loan to purchase and transport charcoal from villages to town for sale. She wants to add to her stock for more profits. She is a hard-working business lady whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and build on it.

loans.use: To purchase and transport charcoal from villages to town for sale.

loans.name: Lobe (Help Me) Group

texts.en: Klubo is a 44 year old married woman and the mother of 4 children. She stopped her education at the 4th grade. All four of her children are college students. She sells dry goods and dry coconuts. For the past 4 years, she has been having difficulty accessing loans to finance or improve her business. Now that her prayers have been answered, she dreams of having a shop of her own to sustain her children and herself.

loans.use: Additional dry coconuts, oil etc

loans.name: Luzbella

texts.en:
Mrs. Luzbella T. is a 59-year-old married woman with 9 children. She lives in Brgy. Paraiso, Sagay Negros Occidental. Raising a family with 9 children is not easy. When she saw how heavy the burden was for her husband, she thought of ways of helping her husband, if only in just a small way, to lessen the burden of their family expenses.

A fine cook, Luz, as she is commonly called, decided to make use of her skills and talents in cooking to supplement the income that her husband brings home. She joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 so that she could have access to unsecured or non-collateral loans to start her business, which currently nets PHP 2,000 per month on average.

Now on her 11th loan cycle, Luz wants to borrow PHP 11,000 as additional capital for her food business.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Greetings from Kigali-Rwanda,

N. is 47 years old, married to one woman.  He produces a monthly income of 300,000 which he used to support 7 children - ages of 19,16,13,11,9,7, and 5.  On top of these children, he also cares for 9 dependents.

He has 20 years of experience in selling fish.  He works each day from 5:00 AM to 7:00 PM with earns him a monthly profit is 100,000 RWF. 

Now he needs his first loan of 500,000 RWF from Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, he will be able to expand his business through purchasing more fish and with that expansion, he has hopes of increasing his monthly profit.

By using this loan, Isaac believes he will be able to pay school fees of his children, build his own house, get more food for his family and even save some money for the future.

loans.use: Fish

loans.name: Kasokoso Central 2 West Naigaga Jalia Group

texts.en:
Jalia  N. is twenty-five years old. She is married and has three children. One of her children is in school, so she cares for two dependents who are also in school. 

She has been selling new and used clothes for five years. She is using the loan to purchase clothes, both new clothes and used clothes, to sell. She is adding more stock to what she has for sale. She is an encouraging business lady whose future hope is to construct a house.

loans.use: To buy new and used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Be Sure Group

texts.en: Famata is illiterate. She is married and has 4 children, almost all of whom are high school graduates. She also has 2 orphans who live with her. She has been selling cooked food for two years. She is challenged by a lack of financing. She dreams of improving her business and opening a restaurant that is the best, of course. She also thinks of construction and buying good medical attention for her children and herself.

loans.use: Additional chairs, bags of rice, etc

loans.name: Las Pioneras Group

texts.es: El grupo “Las Pioneras” esta representado por L. señora Sandra Iris y conformada por 12 miembros que en sus mayoría se dedican a L. venta D. barrotes en tiendas D. barrio, venta D. comida, videos, material D. limpieza y batidos otros se dedican a L. pintura D. casas y otras a L. confección D. prendas D. vestir. L. competencia no les preocupa mucho ya que cada una es dueña D. sus casetas y saben como salir adelante gracias a su experiencia y su dedicación a sus negocios. El financiamiento es para L. adquisición D. más mercadería para hacer crecer sus ingresos y materiales e insumos que ayuden a incrementar sus ingresos para mejorar así L. calidad D. vida D. sus familias. En cuanto a L. experiencia D. créditos solidarios muchas D. las socias ya contaban con elL. gracias a anteriores financiamientos con otras instituciones por lo que conocen L. responsabilidad y L. unidad que se requiere para adquirir L. confianza y el apoyo D. L. Fundación Agrocapital.
texts.en:
The group “Las Pioneras” (the Pioneers) is led by Sra. Sandra Iris and is comprised of 12 members. The majority of the group is involved in retail businesses that sell groceries, food, videos, cleaning supplies, and milkshakes. Other members are engaged in house painting and tailoring. They are not worried about the competition and each member maintains a vending location. They know how to get ahead because of their experience and dedication to their businesses.

This group loan will be used acquire merchandise, materials, and supplies that will help the members increase their earnings so that they can improve the quality of life for their families. Many of the members have previous experience working in solidarity groups and with other financial institutions, so they are aware that responsibility and cooperation is required in order to gain the confidence and support of Fundación Agrocapital.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Dinah

texts.en:
Dinah Kwamboka is 36 years old. She is married to Caleb Bosire, who is 40 years and is a barber by profession, and they have been blessed with three children, Kevin, Miriam and Sarah.They live in Eastern Nairobi in a a semi-slum area known as Kware.

Dinah Kwamboka has run her business for the last year. She will use the loan to expand  and start processing cereals and eventually start a retail shop.

loans.use: STOCKING CEREALS (BEANS, MAIZE, WHOLEMONG, PEAS)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For growing corn and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es:
Andrea es socia del Bancomunal Virgen de las Mercedes.
Andrea es casada tiene 75 años, tiene cinco hijos que son independientes.  
Andrea siempre se ha dedicado a su casa, hasta que decidió poner una bodega en su casa pero cerró por que daba mucho crédito las clientas,  le debían mucho  se descapitalizo, cerró por un buen tiempo. Hasta que ingreso a Finca y con el préstamo que le dieron nuevamente abrió su bodega. 
Desde que Andrea esta en Finca aprendió ahorrar y a  invertir mas  en su negocio.
Necesita un préstamo de  800 soles para la compra de cervezas y gaseosas para surtir su bodega.
El sueño de Andrea es que su negocio crezca cada vez más.
texts.en:
Andrea is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen de las Mercedes”. She is 75 years old, married, and the mother of 5 children, all of whom are independent. Andrea always focused her time at home until she decided to start a grocery store from her house. Her business closed because she extended too much credit to her customers, which caused the business to lose money.

When Andrea joined FINCA, she used her initial loan to reopen her grocery store. Since then, she has learned how to save money and invest more into her business.

She currently needs a loan of 800 soles to restock her store with beer and sodas. Andrea hopes to keep her business growing.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beer & sodas

loans.name: Good Luck Group

texts.en:
Harris is the leader of the Good Luck lending group. He is a high school graduate and the father of four children. His business activity is the sale of dry goods (onions, pepper, rice, oil, and so on): he has been doing this for the past five years.

He views illness as his greatest challenge.

He dreams of improving his business to the level of a shop, and eventually he hopes to enable himself to build a home for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy dry goods for sale

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
Préstamo anterior: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=102616&_tpos=f&_tpg=h
Sabina  es socia del Bancomunal Virgen D. las Mercedes.
Sabina, tiene su bodega-bazar,  lamentablemente pasó por una gran dificultad, salió  a visitar a un pariente cerrando su tienda y cuando regresó a su casa lamentablemente le habían robado vaciándole toda su tienda,  cuando ella llegó solo vio sus mostradores(vitrinas) vacíos, se llevaron los sacos D. arroz azúcar, dulces, casi toda su mercadería. 
Sabina necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles, para la compra D. abarrotes, aceite arroz, azúcar, fideos. Pues desea continuar con su negocio
El préstamo siempre le ayuda, en este caso será para surtir su bodega
El sueño D. Sabina es  levantar su tienda nuevamente.
texts.en:
Sabina is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen D. las Mercedes”. She operates a grocery store/bazaar. Unfortunately, she went through great difficulty. She closed her store so that she could leave town to visit a relative. When she returned, she discovered that her store had been burglarized. The only things that remained were her display cases. The thieves took sacks of rice, sugar, candy, and almost all of her remaining merchandise. Sabina needs a loan of 2000 soles in order to buy grocery items such as oil, rice, sugar and noodles. She hopes to continue her business. Her loans have always been a great help, and in this case, it will enable her to stock her store. Sabina hopes to raise her business to a new level. Click HERE to view Sabina's previous loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grocery items such as oil, rice, sugar and noodles

loans.name: Womenegee Group

texts.en: Lorpu, an illiterate Liberian married mother  with six children, has been involved in the sale of food for the past eight years. Within the Zorzor, Yeala Road area, Lorpu faces challenges of finance, with months sometimes passing without any income. Her goal is to have a restaurant of her own and to adequately educate her children and provide them with good medical care.

loans.use: To purchase bags of rice, gallons of oil, bags of onions, etc.

loans.name: Adegboye

texts.fr: Cet homme est marié et a 02 personnes à sa charge, il a ouvert en 2006 dans le quartier Tokoin Séminaire à Lomé sa petite boutique qu'il a appelé "ADE SERVICE",dans sa boutique il fait des photocopies, traitement de texte, reliure et autres. Actuellement sa photocopieuse est en panne,ce qui a réduit son chiffre d'affaire de ses derniers jours,il sollicite par conséquent auprès de WAGES un crédit  pour acheter une photocopieuse et rehausser son chiffre d'affaire.
texts.en:
This is a man who is married and has two people to support.  In 2006, in the Tokoin Séminaire district, he opened a small shop he calls "ADE SERVICE".  In his shop, he offers photocopying, word processing, book-binding, and more.  Currently, his photocopier is malfunctioning, which has reduced his sales figures in recent days.  As a result, he is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy a photocopier and to raise up his sales again.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a photocopier

loans.name: Mauricia

texts.es:
Mauricia es socia del Bancomunal Virgen de las Mercedes.
Mauricia es conviviente tiene 50 años, cinco  hijos el menor tiene 10 años y esta estudiando  en la escuela estatal.
Mauricia trabajaba en una casa cocinando por mucho tiempo, ella se dedica también a la venta de productos de belleza por catalogo, por las tardes, sus amigas del Bancomunal la animaron a que ponga un negocio  ella decidió ponerse a vender jugos, se compro una carreta y se puso a vender en  un paradero, hace un año y medio.  
Desde que esta en Finca ella aprendió ahorrar, aprendió a ser emprendedora y que ella puede superase y crecer en el negocio.
Mauricia necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles, para la compra de un carrito sanwichero
El sueño de Mauricia es tener otro negocio, esta pensando en poner un restaurante junto con su hija.
texts.en:
Mauricia is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen de las Mercedes”. She is 50 years old, in a common law marriage, and has 5 children. Her youngest child is 10 years old and attends a state school.

Mauricia works at home, cooking most of the time. In the afternoons, she also sells beauty products through a catalog. Her friends from the Communal Bank encouraged her to start her own business. Mauricia decided to sell juices, so she bought a cart and began selling at a bus stop. She has been doing this now for a year and a half.

Since joining FINCA, Mauricia has learned how to save money and develop as an entrepreneur so that she can overcome obstacles and grow her business. She is requesting a loan of 1600 soles to buy a sandwich cart. Mauricia dreams of starting another business and is thinking about opening a restaurant with her daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a sandwich cart

loans.name: Raul

texts.es:
Raul trabaja como transportista publico asalariado, tiene su casa propia tiene tres hijos que depende de él, la esposa trabaja con el de ayudante de bus;  estas dos actividades son sus principales F. de ingreso; su domicilio esta ubicado en la  zona de Villa Tunari de la ciudad de el Alto.

El crédito lo destinará para la construcción de un baño que le ofrecerá mejores comodidades, porque en este momento esta compartiendo el baño con su hermano.
 
Es el primer con crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el préstamo solicitado.
texts.en:
Raul works as a salaried bus driver. He lives in his own home and has three dependent children. His wife works as his assistant on the bus. Their two jobs are their main sources of income. Their home is located in the Villa Tunari area of the city of Alto.

Raul is requesting a loan to build a bathroom to improve his family’s living conditions. At the moment, he has to share a bathroom with his brother.

This is his first loan with IMPRO. The results of his evaluation qualify him for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a bathroom

loans.name: Karen Daisy

texts.es:
Karen es socia del Bancomunal Virgen de las Mercedes.
Karen es conviviente tiene 29 años, no tiene hijos, estudio computación, pero no lo ejerce. 
Karen tenía un puesto de ferretería en el mercado del Callao, y ayudaba a su mamá en la venta de menú, pero tenia que cerrar su puesto. Tuvo que decidir cerrar su negocio de ferretería por que quedaba muy lejos, ella  vive en Villa el Salvador y la distancia en tiempo es de 1 hora y media; decidió poner con su esposo una tienda de lubricantes en Villa el Salvador desde hace cinco años.
Desde que esta en Finca aprendió a ser solidaria y aprendió más sobre negocio.
Karen necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles para la compra de aceites, cables y repuestos de carro. 
El sueño de Karen es que su negocio crezca para poder comprar el local donde tiene su negocio.
texts.en:
Karen is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen de las Mercedes”. She is 29 years old, in a common law marriage, and does not have any children. Karen studied computer science, but does not currently work in that field.

At first, Karen helped her mother sell prepared foods, but she eventually had to close her business. She then operated a vending post selling hardware at the market in Callao. Karen lives in Villa el Salvador, which is 1 ½ hours distance away. She elected to close her hardware business because it was too far to travel. Karen decided to go into business with her husband to open a lube shop in Villa el Salvador, which has been in business now for 5 years.

Since joining FINCA, Karen has learned more about business and how to be supportive of her other group members. She currently needs a loan of 1200 soles to purchase motor oil, cables, and automobile spare parts. Karen hopes that her business will grow so that she can purchase the location on which her business is situated.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase motor oil, cables, and automobile spare parts

loans.name: Leordy

texts.en: Mrs. Leordy L. lives in Brgy. Lopez Jaena, a village located in Sagay City, Negros Occidental. Having five children made life challenging for Leordy and her husband. The need to feed, clothe, shelter and educate their children made Leordy even more determined to help her husband support their family so that her children would not be disadvantaged. Having no idea where to get capital, Leordy was stumped until a friend invited her to join NWTF-Project Dungganon where she could have access to non-collateral loans to start her business. With her first loan, Leordy put up a small "sari-sari" or general store and was able to help her husband with the basic necessities of their family. Leordy discovered that she had the talent to run a business. A few years later, with the profits she earned from her general store and subsequent loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she was able to expand her business to include a small "carinderia" or eatery that sells cooked food to her neighbors. She now earns about PHP 45,000 per month from her various business activities. For her 8th loan, Leordy wants to borrow PHP 11,000 to add to her capital so that she can sustain the momentum of her businesses. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store and carinderia

loans.name: Zeleztia Group

texts.en: Gayduo, a 26-year-old illiterate divorced mother of a nine-year-old, is currently involved in the sale of clothes. “My greatest challenge has been the lack of finance,” she said.  Her business goal is have a shop of her own in the area,  and she dreams of building a two-bedroom house for her and her child.

loans.use: To purchase goods, ladies wear, etc.

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.es:
Vanesa trabaja en el Hotel Sucre ubicado en la ciudad de La Paz en el servicio de limpieza, por la noche esta estudiando en la universidad Publica El Alto; vive con su madre y sus dos hermanos menores, su domicilio esta ubicado en la  zona Brasil de la ciudad de el Alto.

El crédito lo destinará para comprar una impresora para la computadora que ella tiene, misma que le ayudará para poder facilitar sus trabajos que tiene   en la universidad.
 
Es el segundo crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago le permite acceder a otro préstamo solicitado por la prestataria.
texts.en:
Vanessa works on the housekeeping staff at the Hotel Sucre in the city of La Paz. At night, she attends classes at the public university in El Alto. She lives with her mother and two younger brothers in their home located in the Brasil district of El Alto.

Vanessa is requesting a loan to buy a printer to go along with the computer she already owns. This will help her with her college studies.

This is Vanessa’s second loan with IMPRO. Her excellent payment history enabled her to access another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a printer to help with her university studies

loans.name: Amivi Julienne

texts.fr:
cette dame exerce depuis 2001 à Adidogomé le commerce de charbon de bois, elle dispose d'une clientèle élevée. son stock de marchandises a connu une baisse. pour maintenir sa clientèle, elle veut vite se réapprovisionner et sollicite auprès de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 25 sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport.
Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
Since 2001, this woman has been doing commerce in charcoal.  She has a large number of customers.  Her stock of merchandise has experienced a drop.  To maintain her customer base, she wants to stock up again quickly and is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 25 sacks of charcoal and to ensure their transport.  She is married and the mother of two children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita se dedica a la fabricación de instrumentos musicales los cuales vende en las diferentes ferias de la ciudad, su esposo es músico de banda esa es la principal fuente de ingreso con lo que cubre la manutención de sus cuatro hijos, vive en casa propia que esta ubicada en la Zona complemento Yunguyo de la ciudad de El Alto.
 
El préstamo lo destinará la compra de madera, pegamento, venesta y otros, para la fabricación de instrumentos musicales y así poderlos vender en la ferias.
 
Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada califica para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado por Margarita.
texts.en:
Margarita manufactures musical instruments and sells them at different fairs throughout the city. Her husband is a musician in a band. Margarita’s business is the main source of income to cover the living expenses for her four children. They live in their own home in the developed area of Yunguyo in the city of El Alto.

Margarita will use her loan to buy different types of wood, glue, and other supplies needed to make musical instruments that she can sell at the fairs. This is her first loan with IMPRO. The results of her evaluation indicated she is qualified for an approved loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials for making musical instruments

loans.name: God's Favor Group

texts.en: Harrison is a high school graduate and a single parent to four children (ages one through ten at the first grade level). He also cares for two orphans.  For the past three years, he has been involved in a dry goods business. He has been facing financial difficulty for several months now but plans to have a shop of his own and dreams of caring for his children's educational and medical needs.

loans.use: To purchase goods such as sardines, butter, onions, etc

loans.name: Sifa

texts.en:
Greetings from Kigali-Rwanda

Sifa is 29 years old, she is married ,she has three children with the ages of 12,10,4 and one dependent.

Sifa owns a small shop selling clothes in Nyabugogo market at Kigali since 1998.She works every day from 8:00 AM to 8:00 PM and the monthly profit is 150,000 RWF.

Sifa is requesting her first  loan of 500,000 RWF from  Vision Finance Company s.a   .With this new loan, Sifa hopes to expand her business through purchasing more clothes for sales and as she will be getting more profits, she hopes also to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: clothes

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Préstamo anterior: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=102639&_tpos=f&_tpg=h
Juana es socia del Bancomunal Virgen de las Mercedes.
Juana se dedica hace doce años a la venta de tamales, ella vende en su casa, también reparte en las panaderías y vende a sus vecinos, también se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza por pedidos.
Juana necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles para la compra de  productos de belleza y la compra de productos para hacer tamales, hoja de plátano, maíz.    
Desde que esta en Finca  aprendió buenas cosas a compartir, ser unida con sus compañeras.
El sueño de Juana es tener un restaurante y vender más tamales.
texts.en:
Juana is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen de Las Mercedes”. For twelve years, she has been selling tamales from her home. She also distributes her tamales to bakeries and sells them directly to her neighbors. In addition, she sells beauty products upon order. Juana needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy beauty products and ingredients for making tamales, such as banana leaves and corn. Since joining FINCA, she has learned many good things to share with others and how to bond with the other members. Juana dreams of having her own restaurant and selling more tamales. Click HERE to view Juana's previous loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beauty products & ingredients for making tamales

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es: César tiene 34 años, es una persona con gran sentido del humor, hace varios años que vive con  la madre de sus 3 hijos en la casa de sus suegros. La agricultura es su mayor pasión, es por eso que trabaja con mucha dedicación en sus chacras, la cuales son arrendadas y siembra papas y arvejas. Una vez cosechados, sus productos los comercializa en el mercado principal de la ciudad de Tarma. La mayoría de las veces César prefiere trabajar solo porque tiene hijos muy pequeños y aun requieren de mucho cuidado, en vista de eso, a su esposa no trabaja en los cultivos y sólo le lleva el almuerzo hasta que crezcan sus nenes. Por el momento, César está muy ansioso por abonar sus arvejas para apurar su  tercera cosecha en este año. Este es su 5to préstamo con MFP, durantes los ciclos anteriores pagó puntualmente sus cuotas y se compromete a seguir haciéndolo de la misma manera. Por otro lado, en su banco comunal sus bromas son causantes de las carcajadas del resto de sus compañeros, por lo que sus reuniones con muy amenas. El dinero que ahora solicita es para comprar 10 sacos de fertilizantes químicos y menciona que está muy agradecido por la oportunidad de crédito.
texts.en:
César is 34 years old and has a great sense of humor. He and his wife have three children and they all live in the house of his in-laws. Farming is his greatest passion and he is very dedicated to his work in the fields. César’s farmland is leased and he puts it to use by planting potatoes and peas. During the harvest season, his products are sold in the main market in the city of Tarma. Most of the time, César prefers to work alone because his children are very young and require much attention. TherefO., his wife does not work in the fields and only shows up to deliver lunch after the children have been fed.

At the moment, César is anxious to fertilize his crop of peas in order to speed up his third harvest of the year. He received his 5th loan with MFP and has repaid his previous loans on time. He promises to continue doing the same with this current loan. At his communal bank meetings, César’s jokes stir up a lot of laughter among the other members, which makes their time together mO. enjoyable. The money he requested will be used to buy 10 bags of chemical fertilizers. He says he is grateful for this opportunity.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Vera Cruz Group

texts.es: El grupo “Vera Cruz” esta representado por la señora Cinda y esta conformada por 13 miembros los cuales se dedican a distintas actividades la mitad D. las socias se dedica a la venta D. zapatos y a la elaboración D. prendas D. vestir, el resto D. las socias se dedica a la panadería y a la venta D. abarrotes en tiendas D. barrio, los socios se dedican al transporte público D. pasajeros. La competencia a nivel comercial o D. venta D. productos es alta ya que existe variedad D. producto y D. todo precio por lo que los socios tienen que esforzarse para sacar adelante sus negocios realizando prendas mas acorD. al los cambios en el mercado. El destino del financiamiento es para la adquisición D. materia prima como telas y mercadería como abarrotes para incrementar su stock D. venta y repuestos para sus vehículos que ayudara a los socios a mejorar sus ingresos y por enD. a brindar a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida. La experiencia D. las socias radica en grupos anteriormente formados en otras instituciones por lo que conocen la modalidad D. trabajo D. los grupos solidaR. y saben como trabajar juntas para tener un mayor beneficio.
texts.en:
